revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | name = Feeding Everyone No Matter What: Managing Food Security After Global Catastrophe. | image = Cover_Feeding_Everyone.jpg | caption = | authors = David Denkenberger, [[Joshua M. Pearce]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[Academic Press]] | release_date = December 2014 | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 978-0-12-802150-7 | oclc = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} ''''' Feeding Everyone No Matter What: Managing Food Security After Global Catastrophe''''' is a book written by David Denkenberger and [[Joshua M. Pearce]] and published by [[Elsevier]] under their [[Academic Press]].
[[Food storage]] for the entire global population is the only historical solution for a global disruption of conventional [[agriculture]] due to [[global catastrophic risks|global catastrophes]] such as [[abrupt climate change]] and [[nuclear winter]], despite three decades of awareness of the problem.<ref>Bostrom, N & Cirkovic, MM. 2008, ''Global Catastrophic Risks'', Oxford University Press, New York.</ref> But for large global catastrophes, at least five years of supplies are needed because agriculture would be hampered for that time. This large of a stockpile is economically prohibitive on a global scale or even within the US.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Wisconsin Ag Connection - Michigan News - Bacterial Slime: It's What's for Dinner|url = http://www.wisconsinagconnection.com/story-regional.php?tble=MI2014&ID=1117|website = www.wisconsinagconnection.com|access-date = 2014-11-26|publisher = Wisconsin Agriculture Connection}}</ref> The number of global catastrophes that apply is large and the book analyzed five crop-destroying catastrophes (sudden climate change, super-weeds, super-bacteria, super-pests and super-pathogens) and three sunlight-extinguishing events ([[supervolcano]] eruption, asteroid or [[comet impact]], and nuclear winter).<ref name="Messinger">[http://phys.org/news/2014-11-bacterial-slime-survivalist-solution-catastrophic.html] Danny Messinger. "Bacterial slime may be survivalist solution to catastrophic crop failure." Phys.org, Nov 20, 2014</ref>
The book '''''Feeding Everyone No Matter What''''' proposes more than 10 solutions for providing the global food supply according to ''Discovery News''.<ref>[http://news.discovery.com/human/10-foods-you-could-eat-after-a-global-catastrophe-141120.htm 10 Foods You Could Eat After a Global Catastrophe] Jennifer Viegas. Discovery News, Nov 20, 2014</ref>
The study that is the foundation of the book involves [[interdisciplinarity]] and gives instructions for the [[survivalism]] movement. ''Feeding Everyone No Matter What'' has been covered extensively by the international media.<ref name="Messinger" /><ref>[http://io9.com/a-guide-to-the-most-nutritious-post-apocalypse-cuisine-1675341435/all] - Mark Strauss. "A Guide To The Most Nutritious Post-Apocalypse Cuisine." io9 Dec 26, 2014</ref><ref>[https://c-realm.com/2014/10/page/2/] – KMO. "CRV114" C realm podcast Oct 10, 2014</ref><ref>[http://instantteleseminar.com/?eventid=63619950] - David Denkenberger. "New Backup Food Solutions For Catastrophes." American Preppers Network Jan 8, 2015</ref><ref>[http://hmongproperty.com/X0xwejQweGFEeE05] - "Feeding Everyone No Matter What." HMONG HUB music video online Nov 20, 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.alkeenana.com/videos/watch/_Lpz40xaDxM/feeding-everyone-no-matter-what.html] - "Feeding Everyone No Matter What." Alkeenana News channel Nov 20, 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.frequency.com/video/feeding-everyone-no-matter-what/207139305?cid=4-949] - "Feeding Everyone No Matter What." Frequency Nov 20, 2014</ref><ref name=":1">[https://www.seeker.com/10-foods-you-could-eat-after-a-global-catastrophe-1769299254.html] - Jennifer Viegas. "10 Foods You Could Eat After a Global Catastrophe." Seeker, Nov 20, 2014</ref><ref>[http://derstandard.at/2000009902616/Welche-Nahrung-uns-ueber-einen-nuklearen-Winter-braechte] - "Welche Nahrung uns über einen nuklearen Winter brächte." derStandart.at 1-11-2015</ref><ref>[http://www.msn.com/nl-nl/nieuws/wetenschapentechnologie/wat-eten-we-bacterieslijm/ar-BBfykru] - "Wat eten we? Bacterieslijm!" MSN News (Dutch) Nov 24, 2014</ref> [[Io9]] writes that it takes into account potential realistic scenarios, such as crop blights and nuclear winter. [[Seeker (media company)|Seeker]] covered some of the foods recommended for a catastrophe.<ref name=":1" /> Michigan Tech News interviewed author [[Joshua Pearce]] on the solutions presented in the book.<ref name=":0" />
''Feeding Everyone No Matter What'' is also known by organizations working on the prevention of Global Catastrophic Risks. [[Future of Life Institute]] published an article by author Dave Denkenberger<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://futureoflife.org/2015/01/31/feeding-everyone-no-matter-what/|title="Feeding Everyone No Matter What" Dave Denkenberger, January 31, 2015|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and the [[Centre for the Study of Existential Risk]] published his lecture on the book.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cser.ac.uk/resources/feeding-everyone-no-matter-what/|title="Feeding Everyone No Matter What" Dave Denkenberger, Nov 30, 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> ''Feeding Everyone No Matter What'' was used as a resource in the [[Global Challenges Foundation]] Annual Report on Global Risks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://globalchallenges.org/en/our-work/annual-report/annual-report-2017|title=Annual Report On Global Risks, Global Challenges Foundation 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
''Feeding Everyone No Matter What'' proposes a fall-back plan for the worst catastrophes such as a [[Supervolcano|Supervolcano erupting.]]<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/07/here-s-how-world-could-end-and-what-we-can-do-about-it|title=Here’s how the world could end—and what we can do about it|date=2016-07-08|work=Science {{!}} AAAS|access-date=2018-05-04|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/11157_2015_16|title=SpringerLink|last=Donovan|first=Amy|last2=Oppenheimer|first2=Clive|date=2016|publisher=Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg|series=Advances in Volcanology|pages=1–16|language=en|doi=10.1007/11157_2015_16}}</ref> It outlines the cost-effectiveness of alternative foods for disaster preparedness.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Barrett|first=Anthony Michael|date=2017-09|title=Value of Global Catastrophic Risk (GCR) Information: Cost-Effectiveness-Based Approach for GCR Reduction|url=https://pubsonline.informs.org/doi/abs/10.1287/deca.2017.0350|journal=Decision Analysis|language=en|volume=14|issue=3|pages=187–203|doi=10.1287/deca.2017.0350|issn=1545-8490}}</ref> ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'', goes over the book's plan for feeding everyone in the case of the sun being blocked.<ref name=":2" /> Alternative foods can be developed to respond to agriculturally damaging catastrophes all over the world.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Daneshi-Maskooni M, Shab-Bidar S, Badri-Fariman M, Aubi E, Mohammadi Y, Jafarnejad S, Djafarian K | title = Questionnaire-based Prevalence of Food Insecurity in Iran: A Review Article | journal = Iranian Journal of Public Health | volume = 46 | issue = 11 | pages = 1454–1464 | date = November 2017 | pmid = 29167763 | pmc = 5696684 }}</ref> The Global Catastrophic Risk Institute sees this as one piece of the assessing and preparing for [[Global catastrophic risk|Global catastrophic risks.]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Baum|first=Seth|last2=Barrett|first2=Anthony|date=2017-10-02|title=Towards an Integrated Assessment of Global Catastrophic Risk|url=https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3046816|language=en|location=Rochester, NY}}</ref>
== Claims == The authors, David Denkenberger and [[Joshua Pearce]], claim alternate food sources could feed everyone even if the sun is blocked by catastrophes like [[nuclear winter]], [[supervolcano]] eruption, or large [[asteroid]]/[[comet]] impact. At first this appears unlikely because malnutrition and hunger-related disease now{{when?|date=November 2018}} kill 6.5 million children under five years old each year.<ref>United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) 2006.“[http://www.unicef.org/sowc06/ The state of the World’s children.]” 148.</ref> This is because the book focuses on what is technically possible and assumes global cooperation. The solutions also address crises including [[abrupt climate change]], super weeds, super crop [[Pest (organism)|pest]]s (animals, e.g. insects), super [[bacteria]] (e.g. disrupts beneficial bacteria) and super crop [[pathogen]]s. The solution using fossil fuel energy source is natural gas digesting bacteria.<ref>[http://www.unibio.dk/] "UniBio A/S - turns NG to fish food." Accessed February 2015</ref>
A solution if the sun is not completely blocked is [[ocean fertilization]] because 0.1% of the ocean area undergoes coastal upwelling (bringing nutrients to the surface) and yet this produces 50% of the world's fish catch.<ref>Wallace, J. & Hobbs, P. 1977 ''Atmospheric Science''. New York: Academic Press.</ref> [[Ruminant]]s and other grazers can digest [[dietary fiber]], but do not have enough offspring to feed everyone within 5 years.<ref>D.C. Denkenberger and J. M. Pearce. ''Feeding Everyone No Matter What: Managing Food Security After Global Catastrophe'', Elsevier, San Francisco, 2014, pp. 71-72.</ref> [[Mushroom]]s can grow directly on wood without sunlight.<ref>Hazeltine, B. & Bull, C. 2003 ''Field Guide to Appropriate Technology''. San Francisco: Academic Press.</ref> Some [[beetle]]s can digest [[cellulose]].<ref>Aleksandra Walczynska 2007 "Energy budget of wood-feeding larvae of Corymbia rubra (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae)." ''Eur. J. Entomol.'' 104, 181–185.</ref>
[[Cellulosic biofuel]] production typically already creates sugar as an intermediate product.<ref>Langan, P., Gnanakaran, S., Rector, K. D., Pawley, N., Fox, D. T., Chof, D. W. & Hammelg, K. E. 2011 "Exploring new strategies for cellulosic biofuels production." ''Energy Environ. Sci.'' 4, 3820–3833.</ref> There are edible calories in leaves, but there is too much dietary fiber, so solutions include making [[tea]], [[chewing]] and not swallowing the solids, and making [[leaf protein concentrate]].<ref>Kim, K.-Y. & Chung, H.-J. 2000 "Flavor compounds of pine sprout tea and pine needle tea." ''J. Agric. Food Chem.'' 48, 1269–1272.</ref><ref>Kennedy, D. & Leaf for Life 1993 "Leaf concentrate: A field guide for small-scale programs."</ref> [[Biomass]] can be predigested by bacteria so that animals that are poor at digesting cellulose can derive nutrition, such as [[rat]]s<ref>Johnson, R. B., Peterson, D. A. & Tolbert, B. M. 1960 "Cellulose metabolism in the rat." ''J. Nutr.'' 72, 353.</ref> and possibly [[chicken]]s.
As a backup plan, it is even possible that humans could eat this predigested biomass.<ref>D.C. Denkenberger and J. M. Pearce. ''Feeding Everyone No Matter What: Managing Food Security After Global Catastrophe'', Elsevier, San Francisco, 2014, pp. 47-49.</ref> In a sun-obscuring crisis, stored food would last the human population less than one year. The book shows how many of these solutions can be ramped up in less than one year.
This book also addresses other issues, including [[energy supply]], [[water supply]], [[fiber|forest products]], [[human nutrition]], and preserving [[endangered species]]. Furthermore, the book gives instructions for the [[survivalism|prepper]] movement.
==Criticisms== The authors themselves admitted a potential [[moral hazard]] with publishing the solutions, as for example [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] would explicitly state that a motivating factor for reducing the nuclear arsenal of the [[USSR]] was the concept of nuclear winter,<ref>Toon, O, Robock, A & Turco, R 2008, "Environmental consequences of nuclear war," ''Phys. Today'', vol. 61, no. 37, pp. 37–42.</ref> however the politician would neglect to mention the primary "politically incorrect" factor, which was the crumbling [[Soviet economy]] could no longer pay for its militarism. {{citation-needed|date=December 2017}}
However, despite the popularity of the concept of "nuclear winter", there is a clear and present threat of [[Human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] abrupt climate change and the results of efforts to prevent [[global climate change]] have been ineffective.<ref>Yone, GW, Lasco, RD, Ahmad, QK, Arnell, NW, Cohen, SJ, Hope, C, Janetos, AC & Perez, RT 2007, "Perspectives on climate change and sustainability," ''Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change''.</ref> In their analysis, Denkenberger and Pearce argue that the benefits of a food solution backup plan would reduce overall harm to humanity in the global catastrophes over which control is possible and could reduce the damages associated with catastrophes over which humanity has very little or no control (e.g. supervolcanoes).<ref>Denkenberger, D. C., & Pearce, J. M. (2014). [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0016328714001931 Feeding Everyone: Solving the Food Crisis in Event of Global Catastrophes that Kill Crops or Obscure the Sun]. ''Futures''.</ref>
== See also == * [[Famine]] * [[Food security]] * [[Food systems]] * [[Global catastrophic risk]] * [[Survivalism]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://www.appropedia.org/Feeding_Everyone_No_Matter_What Feeding Everyone No Matter What ] on Appropedia.
[[Category:2014 books]] [[Category:2014 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Elsevier books]] [[Category:Books about food and drink]] [[Category:Works about disasters]]

revision.text:
[[Image:SemlaFlickr.jpg|thumb|300px|A typical [[semla]].]]
'''Fettisdagen''' (''The Fat Tuesday'') is the [[Swedish language|Swedish]] name for the Tuesday after the [[Quinquagesima]] and the day between [[Shrove Monday]] and [[Ash Wednesday]]. Because it is the last day before the [[Lent]]en [[Fasting|fast]], a tradition has developed of eating buns, called "fastlagsbullar", "fettisdagsbullar" (Fat Tuesday Buns) or "[[semla]]". The day is also called "White Tuesday" because the buns are made out of white flour.
The day is called "[[Mardi Gras]]" in [[France]], "Carnaval" or "Vastenavond" in [[the Netherlands]], "[[Laskiainen]]" (or "fastlagstisdagen") in [[Finland]], "vastlapäev" in [[Estonia]], and "[[Fastelavn]]" in [[Denmark]]. In the [[United Kingdom|UK]] it is known as [[Shrove Tuesday]] or Pancake Day.
{| class="wikitable" |- !| Year || Date |- || 2005 || 8 February |- || 2006 || 28 February |- || 2007 || 20 February |- || 2008 || 5 February |- || 2009 || 24 February |- ||2010 || 16 February |- || 2011 || 8 March |- || 2012 || 21 February |- || 2013 || 12 February |- || 2014 || 4 March |- || 2015 || 17 February |- || 2016 || 9 February |- || 2017 || 28 February |- || 2018 || 13 February |- || 2019 || 5 March |- || 2020 || 25 February |}
==See also== *[[Shrove Tuesday]]

/* Additions */ "Navajo" isn't the name of the rocket being referenced. As shown later in this very article, it's spelt "Navaho".
revision.text:
"'''Hey Sandy'''" is a song by the American [[indie rock]] band [[Polaris (band)|Polaris]] which serves as the [[theme song]] for the [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]] [[television show]] ''[[The Adventures of Pete & Pete]]''. It's well-known by fans of the show and the band alike for its lyrics, which are not only nearly indecipherable in the first place, but also have generated considerable debate as to their meaning.<ref>[https://www.wired.com/2014/10/polaris-pete-and-pete-band/ Ufberg, Max. "Why a Fake Band From a 1990s Kids' Show Decided to Tour This Year" (''Wired'', October 3, 2014)]</ref>
==Missing lyric== The full lyrics were a subject of speculation for several years until they were (mostly) revealed to fans by band members. One line, the third one and the most difficult one to understand, was purposefully left a mystery by head songwriter [[Mark Mulcahy]].<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-polaris-mark-mulcahy-pete-and-pete-echoplex-20150423-column.html Lloyd, Robert. "Critic's Notebook Polaris rising: Mark Mulcahy's 'Pete and Pete' band comes to town" (''Los Angeles Times'', April 24, 2015)]</ref><ref>[https://pitchfork.com/thepitch/1222-how-nostalgia-for-the-adventures-of-pete-pete-revived-miracle-legion/ Danton, Eric R. "How Nostalgia for 'The Adventures of Pete & Pete' Revived Miracle Legion" (''Pitchfork'', July 8, 2016)]</ref> The song may have referenced the [[Kent State shootings]] and [[Sandra Lee Scheuer]] (being the eponymous "Sandy" of the song), although the actual meaning of the song is in debate.<ref>[http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=4364 Hey Sandy by Polaris (''Songfacts'', 2017)]</ref>
On the DVD set, the subtitles render the third line as "Can you settle to shoot me?", but are not claimed to be an official interpretation of the song's lyrics.
On the DVD commentary for season 2 of ''The Adventures of Pete and Pete'', one of the show's creators, Chris Viscardi, mentions the missing lyric and says, "I've actually become very passionate about keeping that line a secret." There has been a lot of speculation about the missing line, and most people guess that it was originally kept a secret because ''Pete & Pete'' was a family show.
==Additions== The [[Music from The Adventures of Pete & Pete|full album version]] of "Hey Sandy" contains an introduction with a man speaking the following words:
:''Jupiter, or Thor, is perfect. We need Atlas for our long-distance stuff. The Titan will be even better. They shouldn't have canceled Navaho. Wait 'til you see our submarines with Polaris.''
Besides a reference to the band's name, this sound bite is in fact discussing [[United States]] [[ballistic missile]]s designed during the [[Cold War]]: * the intermediate-range [[PGM-19 Jupiter|Jupiter]] and [[PGM-17 Thor|Thor IRBM]] * the [[Atlas (rocket)|Atlas ICBM]], the first successful US intercontinental ballistic missile (for "long-distance stuff") * the [[Titan (rocket family)|Titan family of ICBMs]], successors of Atlas * the cancelled [[SM-64 Navaho]], an experimental cruise missile developed by the [[U. S. Air Force]] * the [[UGM-27 Polaris]], a submarine-launched ballistic missile
The initial sample is abruptly cut off and followed by another sample of a radio transmission, ostensibly from a military base:
:''Attention all personnel, this is CVTS. Base vehicle pre-count operations will start on my mark in 5... 4... 3... 2... 1...''
There is a cover version of "Hey Sandy" by the [[New Jersey]] band Mister Behavior, as well as by [[California]] [[math rock]] band [[Tera Melos]] on their covers EP Idioms, Vol. I
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://pnp.norecess.org/music.html Lyrics as revealed by a Polaris band member]
[[Category:1993 songs]] [[Category:Theme music]] [[Category:Songs based on actual events]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Use British English|date=December 2013}} {{no footnotes|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox play | name = In Extremis:
The Story of Abelard and Heloise | image = HeloiseAbelardGlobe.jpg | image_size =200px | caption =Abelard and Heloise | writer = [[Howard Brenton]] | characters = [[Heloise (abbess)|Heloise]], [[Abelard]], [[Bernard of Clairvaux]] | setting = 12th century France,
particularly [[History of Paris#The Capetians|Paris]] | date of premiere = 27 August 2006 | country of Origin = United Kingdom | original language = English | subject = | genre = }} '''''In Extremis: The Story of Abelard & Heloise''''' is a play by [[Howard Brenton]] on the story of [[Heloise (abbess)|Heloise]] and [[Abelard]], which premiered at the [[Globe Theatre]] on 27 August 2006 with a 15 performance run. The play was directed by [[John Dove (director)|John Dove]] with design by Michael Taylor, and music by [[William Lyons (composer)|William Lyons]]. It was revived for a 2-week run from 15 May 2007 with the same director and most of the same cast. An early draft of the play was written in 1997 at the [[UC Davis|University of California at Davis]] during Brenton's term as its Granada Fellow, and performed by [[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]] students of its Drama Department (with Sarah Pia Anderson directing). ==Synopsis== [[File:In Extremis set.jpg|thumb|350px|left|The set for the second run]] In twelfth century [[Paris]], a new spirit of philosophical and religious enquiry is growing. Within its vanguard is Peter Abelard, a man of great learning, independence of mind, and sensuality. When he enters into an affair with his equally brilliant but disastrously connected student Heloise, his more conservative enemies find just the pretext they need to discredit him and in so doing start a war of ideas. Through the joy and suffering exhibited in this love story set in the Middle Ages, Brenton explores the relationships between logic and religion, humanism and fundamentalism, and faith and power, and projects modern debates on fundamentalism, the Enlightenment and feminism back on this historical situation. ==Plot== Abelard, arguing with his teacher [[William of Champeaux]], sets up a new, [[dialectic]] philosophical school of his own, which proves popular and is even fashionable at the royal court of France. One of his followers is Heloise, with whom he also starts a sexual affair, under the guise of private tuition. His school's success worries Bernard of Clairvaux, who feels it is subjecting [[divine revelation]] to [[rationalism|reason]] and may thus destroy the [[Roman Catholic Church]] and Christianity itself, but for now he merely subjects Abelard to surveillance rather than opposition. Bernard and Abelard do meet, briefly, at the court when Bernard goes there to force the king to give back lands he had seized illegally from a French bishop. Abelard tries to explain that he is not trying to destroy religion but to better understand it through reason using the brain and intellect that God has given him. However, Bernard will not accept this and refuses to accept Abelard's challenge to dispute with him publicly, as Bernard [[dogma]]tically feels he is right and Abelard is wrong and so there is nothing to dispute. Bernard's agents Alberic and Lotholf reveal the affair to Heloise's uncle and surrogate father Fulbert, a [[canon (priest)|canon]] of [[Notre Dame de Paris|Notre Dame]], and he is disgusted by it. Abelard offers to marry Heloise to resolve the situation and remove the disgrace, but she refuses, wanting to be his lover rather than conform to the oppressive norm of medieval marriage. She is smuggled out of Paris to Abelard's sister Denise in Brittany, where she gives birth to their child and waits until two years later Abelard arrives. They return to Paris and get married secretly in Fulbert's garden, but he then refuses to accept a secret marriage and they flee together to a nunnery where Heloise was taught as a girl. There they are kept apart in separate rooms, but secretly consummate their marriage on the altar of the monastery chapel. Abelard is then hunted down and [[castration|castrated]] by Fulbert's cousins in Fulbert's presence, and both he and Heloise are forced to enter monasteries. Bernard at last accepts the challenge to publicly dispute with Abelard before the king and bishops of France, but this turns into a [[show trial]] when Bernard immediately lists 12 points on which Abelard is heretical and Abelard refuses to answer them, maintaining a complete dignified silence and thus forcing his chief supporter the king to back Bernard and declare Abelard a heretic. Abelard and Bernard meet, and fail to make a reconciliation, and then Heloise attends Abelard on his deathbed. After Abelard's death, Bernard burns all of Abelard's heretical works and thus thinks he has won the struggle with him. He then goes to Heloise to affect a reconciliation, but this also fails. The play then ends abruptly with Heloise anachronistically showing Bernard a 20th-century, [[Penguin Books#Penguin Classics|Penguin]] copy of the couple's letters, to prove that he has not erased Abelard and Heloise from history as effectively as he thought. ==Cast of Globe productions== [[File:ExtremisPlay.jpg|thumb|right|Book-cover for the playtext]] *Abelard - [[Oliver Boot]] *Heloise - [[Sally Bretton]] *[[Bernard of Clairvaux]] - [[Jack Laskey]] *Fulbert, Heloise's uncle - [[Fred Ridgeway]] (2006)/ [[Paul Copley]] (2007) *Denise, Abelard's sister - [[Pascale Burgess]] *[[William of Champeaux]] - [[John Bett]] *[[Louis VI of France|Louis VI]] - [[Colin Hurley]] *[[Alberic of Citeaux|Alberic]]* - [[Patrick Brennan (actor)|Patrick Brennan]] (2006) / [[Michael Gould (actor)|Michael Gould]] (2007) *Lotholf* - [[William Mannering]] *Helene, abbess / working woman 1 - Sheila Reid (2006) / [[Eleanor Bron]] (2007) *Student / Courtier / Bishop / Monk - [[Tas Emiabata]] *Berthode - [[Niamh McCann]] *Cousin 1 / Company - [[Andrew Vincent]] *Cousin 2 / Company - [[Simon Muller]] *Francine/Franny - [[Rhiannon Oliver]] *Student / Courtier / Bishop / Monk - [[Alex Kerr (actor)|Alex Kerr]] *Student / Chamberlain / Bishop / Monk - [[Paul Rainbow]] *Marie / Courtier / Nun / Company - [[Frances Thorburn]] (2006)/ [[Jenni Maitland]] (2007) * - Described in the programme by Brenton as "a kind of [[Rosencrantz and Guildenstern]] double act", comic relief from the main themes. ==Reviews== ===2006=== *[http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/14010/in-extremis The Stage] {{broken citation|date=November 2015}} *{{cite news|author=[[Michael Billington (critic)|Michael Billington]]|title=In Extremis |url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/critic/review/0,,1864284,00.html |work=The Guardian |date=4 September 2006 }} *[http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/article627901.ece Times] {{broken citation|date=November 2015}} *[http://enjoyment.independent.co.uk/theatre/reviews/article1438820.ece Independent] {{broken citation|date=November 2015}} *[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2006/09/07/btextremis07.xml Telegraph] {{broken citation|date=November 2015}} *{{cite news|author=[[Lyn Gardner]]|title=In Extremis |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2007/may/24/theatre1 |work=The Guardian |date=24 May 2007 }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Howard Brenton}} [[Category:British plays]] [[Category:2006 plays]] [[Category:Plays set in the 12th century]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:Plays set in France]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} [[Image:Ifmcasquare.jpg|right|thumb]] The '''International Film Music Critics Association''' ('''IFMCA''') is a professional association for [[music journalism|online, print and radio journalists]] who specialize in writing about [[film score|original film and television music]].
==History and purpose== The IFMCA was founded in the late 1990s as the '''Film Music Critics Jury''' by film music journalist [[Mikael Carlsson]] (now the owner of film music record label [[MovieScore Media]]), and after period of inactivity was re-launched in 2003 under its new title.
Its membership includes 65 journalists from 16 different countries who write for such high-profile film and soundtrack-related publications and websites as [[Film Score Monthly]], [[Filmtracks.com|Filmtracks]], [[SoundtrackNet]], [[Music from the Movies]] and [[UnderScores]], as well as more mainstream publications such as [[Ain't It Cool News]], [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]], ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' and the [[Irish Times]]. Members of the IFMCA have also been involved in writing [[liner notes]] for major film music record labels such as [[Film Score Monthly]], [[Varèse Sarabande]], [[Intrada Records]], La-La Land Records and [[Music Box Records]].
The aim of the group is to promote original film music and the work of film music composers as legitimate artists worthy of recognition from the mainstream film and music media, and to publicize the work of its members in pursuing this aim. To this end, the group maintains a website documenting its activities; operates a central online review interface which provides links to articles, reviews and interviews written by its members; organizes an annual awards event, the IFMCA Awards, celebrating music for films written during the preceding year; and is involved in organizing major international film music festivals, such as those in [[Tenerife International Film Music Festival|Tenerife]],<ref>{{cite web |author=Home |url=http://www.fimucite.com/f4/en/ |title=Tenerife International Film Music Festival |publisher=Fimucite.com |accessdate=11 November 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711002151/http://www.fimucite.com/f4/en/# |archive-date=11 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Úbeda]] in Spain,<ref>[http://festival.bsospirit.com/en/index.php ]{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref> [[Kraków]] in Poland,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fmp.org.pl/ |title=Festiwal Muzyki Polskiej |publisher=Fmp.org.pl |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> and the [[World Soundtrack Academy|World Soundtrack Awards]] in [[Ghent]], Belgium.<ref>{{cite web|author=Poland |url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/members/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » Members |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref>
==IFMCA Awards== The organization is responsible for the annual International Film Music Critics Association Awards, the only awards given to composers by active film music journalists, and which are seen by many as a valuable precursor to the [[Academy Awards]] in the absence of a guild for composers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://incontention.com/2010/01/29/international-film-music-critics-nominees/ |title=International Film Music Critics nominees |publisher=Incontention.com |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> They have been called the "Oscars of film music",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.es/agencias/noticia.asp?noticia=704788 |title=Araujo, premio IFMCA a la banda sonora de videojuegos por "Lords of Shadow" |publisher=Abc.es |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> have been featured in major daily newspapers in Spain<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/Pantallas/Sinfonias/videojuego/elpepurtv/20110308elpepirtv_1/Tes |title=Sinfonías en el videojuego: Premio internacional para Óscar Araujo por una banda sonora |publisher=Elpais.com |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> and Portugal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mundoportugues.org/content/1/8810/nuno-malo-eleito-compositor-revelacao-ano-nos-estados-unidos/ |title=Nuno Malo eleito o compositor revelação do ano nos Estados Unidos |publisher=Mundoportugues.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> are recognized by major performing rights organizations such as [[ASCAP]] in the United States<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ascap.com/playback/2011/02/Faces_Places/FilmTV/IFMCA_Awards.aspx |title=ASCAP Composers Score at the IFMCA Awards |publisher=Ascap.com |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> and [[Sociedad General de Autores y Editores|SGAE]] in Europe,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sgae.es/el-compositor-catalan-oscar-araujo-gana-el-premio-a-la-mejor-banda-sonora-2010-para-videojuego-de-la-international-film-music-critics-association/ |title=SGAE: El compositor catalán Óscar Araujo gana el Premio a la Mejor Banda Sonora 2010 para Videojuego de la International Film Music Critics Association |publisher=Sgae.es |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> and most recently have been seen by the video games industry as an important step forward in legitimizing game music as a mainstream creative art form.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kietzmann |first=Ludwig |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2011/02/12/castlevania-lords-of-shadow-soundtrack-nominated-for-2-ifmca/ |title=Castlevania: Lords of Shadow soundtrack nominated for 2 IFMCA awards |publisher=Joystiq.com |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref>
Composers as varied as [[John Debney]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Debney_John.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=5 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606234936/http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Debney_John.pdf# |archive-date=6 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Alexandre Desplat]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alexandredesplat.net/us/bio-e.htm |title=Alexandre Desplat's biography |publisher=Alexandredesplat.net |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> [[Randy Edelman]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.randyedelman.com/bio/bioNF.htm |title=Bio |publisher=Randy Edelman |accessdate=11 November 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927175242/http://www.randyedelman.com/bio/bioNF.htm# |archive-date=27 September 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[George Fenton]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Fenton_George.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=5 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606235217/http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Fenton_George.pdf# |archive-date=6 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Michael Giacchino]],<ref>http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Giacchino_Michael.pdf{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[James Newton Howard]]<ref>http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Howard_James_Newton.pdf{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Mark Isham]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://isham.com/about/bio/ |title=Mark Isham Music – Bio |publisher=Isham.com |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> [[Andrew Lockington]],<ref>{{cite web|author=<!--Biography --> <!-- 20 September 2010--> |url=http://www.andrewlockington.com/?page_id=25 |title=Composer » Biography |publisher=Andrew Lockington |date=20 September 2010 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> [[Abel Korzeniowski]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abelkorzeniowski.com/info |title=Info |publisher=Abel Korzeniowski |date=23 October 2010 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> [[Brian Tyler (composer)|Brian Tyler]],<ref>http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Tyler_Brian.pdf{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Fernando Velázquez (composer)|Fernando Velázquez]]<ref>http://www.gsamusic.com/pdf/Velazquez_Fernando.pdf{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and [[Debbie Wiseman]]<ref>[http://www.debbiewiseman.co.uk/awards.asp ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817135514/http://www.debbiewiseman.co.uk/awards.asp |date=17 August 2009 }}</ref> highlight their IFMCA Award wins and nominations in their official biographies.
===Major award winners=== *1998 Score of the Year: [[Mulan (1998 film)|Mulan]], by [[Jerry Goldsmith]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/1998-fmcj-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 1998 FMCJ Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref> *1998 Composer of the Year: [[Jerry Goldsmith]]
*1999 Score of the Year: [[The Mummy (1999 film)|The Mummy]], by [[Jerry Goldsmith]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/1999-fmcj-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 1999 FMCJ Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref> *1999 Composer of the Year: [[Jerry Goldsmith]]
*2000 - AWARDS NOT GIVEN *2001 - AWARDS NOT GIVEN *2002 - AWARDS NOT GIVEN *2003 - AWARDS NOT GIVEN
*2004 Score of the Year: [[The Incredibles]], by [[Michael Giacchino]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/2004-ifmca-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 2004 IFMCA Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2004 Composer of the Year: [[Michael Giacchino]]
*2005 Score of the Year: [[Memoirs of a Geisha (film)|Memoirs of a Geisha]], by [[John Williams]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/2005-ifmca-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 2005 IFMCA Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2005 Composer of the Year: [[John Williams]]
*2006 Score of the Year: [[Lady in the Water]], by [[James Newton Howard]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/2006-ifmca-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 2006 IFMCA Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2006 Composer of the Year: [[Alexandre Desplat]]
*2007 Score of the Year: [[Atonement (film)|Atonement]], by [[Dario Marianelli]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/awards-archive/2007-ifmca-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » 2007 IFMCA Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2007 Composer of the Year: [[Alexandre Desplat]]
*2008 Score of the Year: [[The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (film)|The Curious Case of Benjamin Button]], by [[Alexandre Desplat]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2009/02/ifmca-announces-its-2008-winners-for-scoring-excellence/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA announces its 2008 winners for scoring excellence |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |date=19 February 2009 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2008 Composer of the Year: [[Danny Elfman]]
*2009 Score of the Year: [[Up (soundtrack)|Up]], by [[Michael Giacchino]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2010/03/ifmca-announces-winners-of-2009-awards/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA announces winners of 2009 Awards |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2009 Composer of the Year: [[Michael Giacchino]]
*2010 Score of the Year: [[How to Train Your Dragon: Music from the Motion Picture|How to Train Your Dragon]], by [[John Powell (composer)|John Powell]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2011/02/ifmca-announces-its-2010-winners-for-scoring-excellence/ |title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA announces its 2010 Winners for scoring excellence |publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |date=26 October 2011 |accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> *2010 Composer of the Year: [[Alexandre Desplat]]
*2011 Score of the Year: [[War Horse (film)|War Horse]], by [[John Williams]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2012/02/ifmca-winners-2011/|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2011|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=23 February 2012}}</ref> *2011 Composer of the Year: [[John Williams]]
*2012 Score of the Year: [[Life of Pi (film)|Life of Pi]], by [[Mychael Danna]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2013/02/ifmca-winners-2012/|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2012|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=21 February 2013}}</ref> *2012 Composer of the Year: [[Danny Elfman]]
*2013 Score of the Year: [[Romeo and Juliet (2013 film)|Romeo and Juliet]], by [[Abel Korzeniowski]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2014/02/ifmca-winners-2013/|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2013|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> *2013 Composer of the Year: [[Abel Korzeniowski]]
*2014 Score of the Year: [[Interstellar (film)|Interstellar]], by [[Hans Zimmer]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2015/02/ifmca-award-winners-2014//|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2014|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=19 February 2015}}</ref> *2014 Composer of the Year: [[Alexandre Desplat]]
*2015 Score of the Year: [[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]], by [[John Williams]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2016/02/ifmca-award-winners-2015//|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2015|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref> *2015 Composer of the Year: [[Michael Giacchino]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2016/02/ifmca-award-winners-2015//|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2015|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref>
*2016 Score of the Year: [[Arrival (film)|Arrival]], by [[Jóhann Jóhannsson]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2017/02/ifmca-winners-2016///|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2016|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 February 2017}}</ref> *2016 Composer of the Year: [[Michael Giacchino]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2017/02/ifmca-winners-2016///|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2016|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 February 2017}}</ref>
*2017 Score of the Year: [[Phantom Thread]], by [[Jonny Greenwood]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2018/02/ifmca-award-winners-2017////|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2017|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref> *2017 Composer of the Year: [[Alexandre Desplat]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusiccritics.org/2018/02/ifmca-award-winners-2017////|title=IFMCA: the International Film Music Critics Association » IFMCA Winners 2017|publisher=Filmmusiccritics.org |accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Mister Gay International |image = |image_border = |size = 150px |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |motto = Human Rights - Equality - Respect - Opportunity |formation = 2005 |type = [[Beauty Pageant]] |headquarters = [[Canada]] |location = |membership = 40+ |language = English |leader_title = President |leader_name = Don Spradlin (President and Director Oceania) |key_people = |num_staff = |budget = }} [[File:Pablo Salvador from Chile International Mr. Gay 2011 - 2012.JPG|thumb|Pablo Salvador International Mr. Gay Titleholder.]] '''Mr. Gay International''' was the first international contest to select an Ambassador or spokesman to support the mission of the sponsoring nonprofit corporation, the Noble Beast Foundation. President of the Noble Beast Foundation is Don Spradlin, who founded and produced the first three Competitions with a team of dedicated volunteers. Carlos Melia, native from Argentina was the second International Mr Gay, elected and crowned in Los Angeles, California in 2008. The last International Mr. Gay titleholder was [[Pablo Salvador Sepúlveda]] from Chile. The competition has been ''de-facto'' replaced by [[Mr Gay World]].
==Mission statement== "(To) advocate International Equal Rights by confirming the essential nature and contributions of gay men to a healthy society where "gay" is not a stereotype"<ref>{{cite web |title=Pageant Aims to Blast Stereotypes |url=http://www.pe.com/localnews/inland/stories/PE_News_Local_D_dspot18.35f7a86.html |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=20 August 2009}}</ref>
== Media Coverage ==
The event explicitly seeks to highlight discrimination against [[LGBTI]] people and provide select positive role models. A number of contestants from a number of countries has faced sanctions for their selection or competition, including Zoltan Parag from [[India]],<ref>http://www.hindustantimes.com/I-m-scared-to-return-to-India/Article1-273159.aspx </ref> [[Taurai Zhanje]] from [[Zimbabwe]], [[Robel Hailu]] from [[Ethiopia]], former Olympian [[Chavdar Arsov]] from [[Bulgaria]], [[Wendelinus Hamutenya]] from [[Namibia]] and Xiao Dai from China.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.timeslive.co.za/world/2012/04/10/mr-gay-world-shakes-african-perceptions |title=Mr Gay World shakes African perceptions |work=timeslive.co.za |year=2012 |quote=Xiao Dai |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/mr-gay-world-contest-goes-ahead-in-johannesburg-despite-threats-7627646.html |title=Mr Gay World contest goes ahead in Johannesburg despite threats |work=[[The Independent]] |publisher=[[Independent News & Media|INM]] |location=[[London, UK|London]] |issn=0951-9467 |oclc=185201487 |accessdate=28 April 2012 |date=9 April 2012}}</ref>
==Titleholders==
===List of Mr Gay International titleholders=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Country/Territory ! Mr. Gay International ! National title ! Location ! Ref |- | [[Mr. Gay International 2011-2012|2011- 2012]] | {{CHI}} | [[Pablo Salvador Sepúlveda]] | [[Mr. Gay Chile]] | [[Los Angeles, California]] | |- | [[Mr. Gay International 2009-2010|2009-2010]] | {{SWI}} | [[Ricco Müller]] | [[Mr. Gay Switzerland International]] | [[Bakersfield, California]] | |- | [[Mr. Gay International 2008|2008]] | {{ARG}} | [[Carlos Melia]], | [[Mr. Gay Argentina]] | [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | |- | [[Mr. Gay International 2006-2007|2006-2007]] | {{ISR}} | [[Nathan Shaked]] | [[Mr. Gay Israel]] | [[Palms Springs]], [[California]] | |- | [[Mr. Gay International 2005|2005]] | {{US}} | [[Jesse Bashem]] | [[Mr. Gay United States]] | [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | |}
==Mr Gay International The Competition== The third edition of International Mr Gay International, took place in Los Angeles, California. [[Carlos Melia]], was crowned as IMG 2008, representing his country of origin as Mr Gay Argentina.<ref>[http://www.edgeptown.com/news////55418/international_mr_gay_picks_winner 'International Mr. Gay Picks Winner"], "Edge", January 26, 2008</ref><ref>"[[Carlos Melia]]", "Wikipedia"</ref> As International Mr. Gay, Carlos traveled extensively, not only in his own community but on a global stage, as an ambassador and spokesperson for equal and human rights, fundraising and endorsing LGBT organizations and events worldwide.<ref>[http://www.mrgaypride.es/noticias_carlos_melia.html "Carlos Meliá Mr. Gay International 2008"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130711084256/http://mrgaypride.es/noticias_carlos_melia.html |date=2013-07-11 }}, "Mr Gay Pride España" 2008</ref>
In 2009, by the end of his reign, after a successful performance, he was invited to join the Board of Directors of [[Mr Gay World]], and appointed Executive Director of Central and South America and the Caribbean.<ref>[http://mrgayworld.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=25:mr-gay-international-2008-works-for-mgw&catid=4:updates&Itemid=108 "International Mr Gay 2011 works for MGW"], ''Mr Gay World website''</ref><ref>[http://mrgayworld.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=115:big-in-south-america&catid=4:updates&Itemid=108 "Big in South America"], ''Mr Gay World website'', January 11, 2010</ref> [[File:Porträt Rimus.png|thumb|upright|Ricco Müller]] The next US Finale was held in San Francisco’s Museum of Performance and Design in November 2008 when Michael Jarvis was named the US Delegate to the IMG. The International Competition was assigned to the [[Philippine]] producers for May 2009, in preparation for the first time the IMG Competition would be produced outside of the United States.
The IMG was scheduled for [[Manila]] in the [[Philippines]] for the summer of 2009, but the Manila team failed to produce the contest hence, competition was moved back to California.<ref>{{cite web |title=INTERNATIONAL MR. GAY COMPETITION MOVES TO MANILA |url=http://www.mrgaycompetition.com/press.htm |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=20 August 2009}}</ref>
The 2009 MGI competition was held in Bakersfield, California where Switzerland’s Ricco Müller proclaimed as the International Mr. Gay title holder for 2009. Rounding up the top five are Australia- 1st Runner Up, USA- 2nd Runner Up, Philippines- 3rd runner up and Puerto Rico- 4th runner up). Ricco Müller is a Student and Artist, Traineeship Daniel Libeskind Architects. Ricco Müller will now work as an International Mr Gay Ambassador to improve the visibility of gay men and Supports for AIDS-aid, Europride 2009 and Deaf Community.
On January 2011, [[Pablo Salvador Sepúlveda]], activist and Teacher of History, competed in the International Mr Gay Competition and won the title. As International Mr. Gay, Pablo Salvador work for the international LGBT community and travel to Chile, Uruguay and Argentina. Pablo appeared on various Radio and Television Stations in Chile as gay spokesman.
==See also==
* [[Mr Gay World]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Recurring events established in 2005]] [[Category:Male beauty pageants]] [[Category:LGBT beauty pageants]] [[Category:Annual events]]

{{Infobox U.S. Courts of Appeals case |Litigants=Jenson v. Eveleth Taconite Co. |Court=[[United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit]] |CourtSeal= |SubmitDate=October 21, |SubmitYear=1997 |DecideDate=December 5, |DecideYear=1997 |FullName=Lois E. Jenson v. Eveleth Taconite Company, et al. |Citations=130 [[F.3d]] [https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/130/1287/634832/ 1287]; 75 Fair Empl. Prac. Cas. ([[Bloomberg BNA|BNA]]) 852,72 Empl. Prac. Dec. ([[CCH (company)|CCH]]) ¶ 45,174; 48 Fed. R. Evid. Ser v. 454 |Prior=139 [[F.R.D.]] 657 ([[D. Minn.]] 1991); 824 [[F. Supp.]] [https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp/824/847/1460561/ 847] (D. Minn. 1993) |Subsequent=Rehearing ''[[en banc]]'' denied, February 18, 1998 |Holding= |Judges=[[Theodore McMillian]], [[Floyd Robert Gibson]], [[Donald P. Lay]] |Majority=Lay |JoinMajority=a unanimous panel |LawsApplied= }} '''''Jenson v. Eveleth Taconite Co.''''', 130 F.3d 1287 (8th Cir. 1997),<ref name=appeal>{{cite court |litigants=Jenson v. Eveleth Taconite Co. |vol=130 |reporter=F.3d |opinion=1287 |pinpoint= |court=[[8th Cir.]] |date=1997 |url=https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/130/1287/634832/ |accessdate=2018-06-14 |quote=}}</ref> was the first [[class action|class-action]] [[sexual harassment]] [[lawsuit]] in the [[United States]]. It was filed in 1988 on behalf of Lois Jenson and other female workers at the EVTAC [[mining|mine]] in [[Eveleth, Minnesota]] on the state's northern [[Mesabi Range]], which is part of the [[Iron Range]].
==Facts== Jenson first began working at the site in March 1975 and along with other women, endured a continuous stream of hostile behavior from male [[employee]]s, including sexual harassment, abusive language, threats, [[stalking]] and intimidation. On October 5, 1984, she mailed a complaint to the Minnesota Department of Human Rights outlining the problems she experienced.<ref>[http://www.humanrights.state.mn.us/ Minnesota Department of Human Rights]</ref> In retaliation, her car tires were slashed a week later. In January 1987, the state's agency requested that Ogelbay Norton Co.,<ref>[http://www.oglebaynorton.com Oglebay Norton] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060619000945/http://www.oglebaynorton.com/ |date=June 19, 2006 }}</ref> a [[Cleveland, Ohio]]-based part-owner of the mine, pay [[United States dollar|US$]]6,000 in punitive damages and $5,000 to Jenson for mental anguish, but the company refused.
On August 15, 1988, attorney [[Paul Sprenger]] filed ''Lois E. Jenson and Patricia S. Kosmach v. Eveleth Taconite Co.'' in U.S. District Court in the [[U.S. District Court for the District of Minnesota|U.S. District Court]] in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota|Minneapolis]]. [[Class-action]] status was requested at the time, and granted by [[James M. Rosenbaum]] on December 16, 1991. Jenson quit working at the mine on January 25, 1992, and was diagnosed with [[post-traumatic stress disorder]] a short time later.
A [[legal liability|liability]] trial began on December 17, 1992, in front of Judge Richard Kyle in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]], and six months later, he ruled that the company should have prevented the misconduct.<ref>{{cite court |litigants=Jenson v. Eveleth Taconite Co. |vol=824 |reporter=F. Supp. |opinion=847 |pinpoint= |court=[[D. Minn.]] |date=1993 |url=https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp/824/847/1460561/ |accessdate=2018-06-14 |quote=}}</ref> The company was ordered to educate all employees about sexual harassment.
Patrick McNulty of [[Duluth, Minnesota|Duluth]] was named [[special master]] a few months later to oversee a trial that would determine the amount of money owed to the women in damages. The retired federal magistrate permitted [[lawyer]]s from the mine company to obtain [[medical records]] of all of the women for their entire lifetimes. Ahead of the trial, the plaintiffs endured long [[Deposition (law)|deposition]]s that explored their personal lives in great detail.
The first half of the trial for damages began in Duluth on January 17, 1995 and lasted until February 10. After a break, it resumed on May 22 and ended on June 13.
On March 28, 1996, McNulty released a 416-page report that called the women "[[wikt:histrionic|histrionic]]," made public details about their private lives, and awarded them an average of $10,000 each. However, the judgment was [[appeal]]ed and reversed by the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit|Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals]] on December 5, 1997.<ref name=appeal/> A new [[jury]] trial on damages was ordered.
==Settlement== On December 23, 1998, just before the trial was set to begin, fifteen women settled with Eveleth Mines for a total of $3.5 million. One of the original plaintiffs, Pat Kosmach, died partway through the case, on November 7, 1994.
The case was documented in the 2002 book ''Class Action'' and a 2005 fictionalized [[film]] version, ''[[North Country (film)|North Country]]''.
==See also== *''[[Hostile Advances: The Kerry Ellison Story]]'' movie about ''[[Ellison v. Brady]]'' which set the "reasonable woman" precedent in sexual harassment law *[[Hostile work environment]] *[[List of class action lawsuits]] *''[[Meritor Savings Bank v. Vinson]]'' *''[[Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services]]'' *[[Oglebay Norton Corporation]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Notes== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061202050813/http://www.ca8.uscourts.gov/opndir/97/12/971147P.pdf U.S. 8th Circuit Court of Appeals case documents] * Class Action: The Story of Lois Jenson and the Landmark Case That Changed Sexual Harassment Law (2003) {{ISBN|0-385-49613-3}} * {{IMDb title | id=0395972 | title=North Country}}
==External links== * {{caselaw source | case = ''Jenson v. Eveleth Taconite Co.'', 130 F.3d 1287 (8th Cir. 1997) | courtlistener =https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/748845/75-fair-emplpraccas-bna-852-72-empl-prac-dec-p-45174-48-fed-r/ | googlescholar = https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=1423730242816254836 | justia =https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/130/1287/634832/ }} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070314002837/http://shsf.invisionzone.com/index.php?s=d3323e12d3ea7b9fac0ed41f254541a4&showtopic=65 Class Action: What Happens When Employers Refuse To Remedy Sexual Harassment], plus interviews
{{DEFAULTSORT:Jenson V. Eveleth Taconite Co.}} [[Category:Business ethics cases]] [[Category:Class action lawsuits]] [[Category:Harassment case law]] [[Category:History of labor relations in the United States]] [[Category:Sexism]] [[Category:Sexual harassment in the United States]] [[Category:United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit cases]] [[Category:United States employment discrimination case law]] [[Category:1988 in United States case law]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Kha b' Nisan |type = Cultural |longtype = Cultural |image = Assyrianculture.jpg |caption = Kha b' Nisan celebration in Nahla region |official_name = {{lang-syr|ܚܕ ܒܢܝܣܢ}} |nickname = |observedby = [[Assyrian people]] |begins = |ends = |scheduling = same day each year |date = 1 April |celebrations = Dancing circles, parades, picnics |observances = |relatedto = [[Akitu]], [[Seharane]], [[Noruz]] }}
'''Kha b' Nisan''' or '''Ha b' Nisin''',<ref>[http://aua.net/News/releases/2006/NewYear2006.pdf AUA Release 26 March 2006.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120035722/http://aua.net/News/releases/2006/NewYear2006.pdf |date=20 November 2008 }}</ref> also ''Ha b' Nison''; {{lang|arc|ܚܕ ܒܢܝܣܢ}} "[[First of April]]", '''Resha d'Sheta'''; {{lang|arc|ܪܫܐ ܕܫܢܬܐ}} "Head of the year" in [[Assyrian Neo-Aramaic|Assyrian]], also known as '''[[Akitu]]''', or '''Assyrian New Year'''<ref>[http://fairfield.yourguide.com.au/news/local/news/entertainment/assyrian-new-year/757487.aspx Michael Chammas. "Assyrian new year". Fairfield Champion. 26 March 2008.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080806082507/http://fairfield.yourguide.com.au/news/local/news/entertainment/assyrian-new-year/757487.aspx |date=6 August 2008 }}{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2009}}</ref> is the [[spring festival]] among the indigenous [[Assyrian people|Assyrians]] of northern [[Iraq]], northeastern [[Syria]], southeastern [[Turkey]] and northwestern [[Iran]], celebrated on 1 April.
The festival has its roots in the ancient [[Mesopotamian religion]] practiced by Assyrians until its gradual demise in the face of [[Syriac Christianity]] between the 1st and 4th centuries AD. Today Assyrians are Christians, with most being adherents of the [[Assyrian Church of the East]], [[Chaldean Catholic Church]], [[Syriac Orthodox Church]], [[Ancient Church of the East]], [[Assyrian Pentecostal Church]] and [[Assyrian Evangelical Church]].
Celebrations involve parades and parties. Some Assyrians wear traditional costume and dance in parks for hours. In Europe, Australia, the United States, Canada and the Caucasus among [[Assyrian Diaspora]] communities, there are often parties with food, music and dance.<ref>[http://media.www.csusignal.com/media/storage/paper1217/news/2008/03/19/CampusLife/Assyrians.Celebrate.New.Year-3275737.shtml Aimie Rivera. "Assyrians celebrate new year". The Signal. 3/19/08.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708212136/http://media.www.csusignal.com/media/storage/paper1217/news/2008/03/19/CampusLife/Assyrians.Celebrate.New.Year-3275737.shtml |date=8 July 2011 }}{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2009}}</ref>
==History== In the [[Julian calendar]], the vernal equinox moved gradually away from 21 March. The [[Gregorian calendar]] reform restored the vernal equinox to its original date, but since the festival was by now tied to the date, not the astronomical event, Kha b' Nisan remains fixed at 21 March in the Julian reckoning, corresponding to 1 April in the Gregorian calendar. The [[Vernal equinox]] is celebrated throughout [[Greater Iran]] as ''[[Noruz]]'' meaning "New Day" on 21 March. However, in the ancient [[Assyria|Assyrian]], [[Akkadian Empire|Akkadian]] and [[Babylonia]]n traditions, the spring festival was celebrated in the first days of the month known as "Nisan"<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=9hhmzVrYPHAC&pg=PA117&lpg=PA117&dq=new+year+nisan+akitu&source=bl&ots=n0nYzub5gc&sig=WTTneJ6-BqOgn-iSzDpUWyDveYw&hl=en&ei=6F-oSdX_IIzVnQeW6JTaDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=8&ct=result E. Elochukwu Uzukwu. Worship as Body Language: Introduction to Christian Worship : an African. Published by Liturgical Press, 1997.]</ref> and the calendar adopted by the ancient Assyrians had the month "Nisan" at the beginning of the calendar<ref>William Ricketts Cooper. "An Archaic Dictionary: biographical, historical and mythological: from the Egyptian, Assyrian, and Etruscan monuments". Published by S. Bagster and Sons, 1876.</ref> lending to the term "Kha b' Nisan", or the "first of Nisan".
In the 1950s, a rising upsurge in [[Assyrian nationalism]] resulted in the creation of an official "[[Assyrian calendar]]" with its [[calendar era|era]] fixed at 4750 BC, inspired by an estimate of the date of the first temple at [[Ashur]] in the [[Ubaid period|Middle Ubaid period]]. In the same spirit, the Akkadian name of the spring festival, ''[[Akitu]]'', was revived. It is essential to consider that the Assyrian people have generally celebrated ''[[Akitu]]'' on the first day of April since 4750 BC and that a creation of an official calendar would aim to unite the Assyrians in their nationalism.
The event is also largely celebrated by Assyrians residing in Syria. Although the Syrian government does not acknowledge the festival, Assyrians still continue with the celebration.<ref>http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/topic,463af2212,46ef83f52,4959de172,0.html</ref> In 2002, Assyrians in Syria celebrated the event with a mass wedding of 16 couples and over 25,000 attendees.<ref>http://www.bethsuryoyo.com/currentevents/6752HomelandCelebration/CelebrationInSyria.html</ref> After the formation of [[Turkey]], Kha b' Nisan along with the [[Nowruz]] were banned from public to celebrate. Assyrians in Turkey were first allowed to publicly celebrate Kha b' Nisan in 2005, after organisers received permission from the government to stage the event, in light of democratic reforms adopted in support of Turkey's EU membership bid.<ref>[http://www.setimes.com/cocoon/setimes/xhtml/bs/features/setimes/newsbriefs/2005/04/11/nb-10 Assyrians Celebrate New Year for First Time in Turkey (SETimes.com)<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://frazer.rice.edu/~erkan/blog/archives/000235.html Erkan's field diary:<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060901140718/http://frazer.rice.edu/~erkan/blog/archives/000235.html |date=1 September 2006 }}{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2009}}</ref> Around 5,000 people "including large groups of visiting ethnic Assyrians from Europe, Syria and Iraq" took part in the Kha b' Nisan celebrations.<ref>[[NYT]] (4 April 2005)[https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/04/international/europe/04turkey.html]</ref>
One of the largest Assyrian New Year celebration took place in Iraq in 2008. Public celebrations were not allowed by [[Saddam Hussein]]'s regime prior to the start of the Iraq war. The event was organized by the [[Assyrian Democratic Movement]] and between 45,000 and 65,000 people took part in the parade.<ref>http://www.helentalia.com/community.htm</ref><ref>http://www.zindamagazine.com/html/archives/2008/04.14.08/index_mon.php#goodmorningassyria {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402152316/http://www.zindamagazine.com/html/archives/2008/04.14.08/index_mon.php |date=2 April 2009 }}</ref>
In 2004, Hon. [[George Radanovich]] of the [[California State Assembly]] recognized the Assyrian New Year and extended his wishes to the Assyrian community in California.<ref>[http://bulk.resource.org/gpo.gov/record/2004/2004_E00370.pdf Congressional Records – Extensions of Remarks]{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2009}}</ref> This was later followed by a letter from the California governor, [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], to the Assyrian community in California congratulating them on the annual celebration.<ref>[http://www.betnahrain.org/Kha-B-Nissan-1.pdf Governor's letter to Assyrian community] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061208195037/http://www.betnahrain.org/Kha-B-Nissan-1.pdf |date=8 December 2006 }}{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2009}}</ref>
==Celebration== Assyrians celebrate Kha b' Nisan by holding social events including parades and parties. They also gather in clubs and social institutions and listen to the poets who recite the story of creation. The men and women wear traditional clothes and dance in parks for hours.
It has also become tradition to hold a parade down King Sargon Blvd in Chicago, Illinois,<ref>[http://www.helentalia.com/community.htm April 2005]</ref> with the Assyrian organizations, churches, and sometimes businesses, each creating a float and participating in the parade.
It is a tradition in Assyrian villages for girls to gather flowers and herbs which are then suspended under the house's roof. The bunches are referred to as "Deqna d' Nisan",<ref>[http://www.bethsuryoyo.com/currentevents/AGNisan6752/NisanEnglish.html Ashor Giwargis. Al-Nahar Newspaper. Beirut, Lebanon. 14 April 2002.]{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2009}}</ref> {{lang|arc|ܕܩܢܐ ܕܢܝܣܢ}} meaning "beard of April/Spring".
==Image gallery== <center> <gallery> Image:Assyriannewyear.gif|Chaldean Church float in Assyrian New Year parade in Chicago, IL. Image:AssyrianAkitu2008.jpg|Assyrian New Year in [[Nohadra]], [[Iraq]] in 2008. </gallery> </center>
==See also== * [[Assyria]] * [[Akitu]] * [[Nowruz]] * [[Seharane]] * [[Sham el-Nessim]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.aina.org/articles/akituandnuroz.pdf Akitu and Newruz] (aina.org) * [http://christiansofiraq.com/norooz.html Kurd's – Persian New Year; its Assyrian – Babylonian origin] (christiansofiraq.com) * [http://www.brasheet.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=64&mode=&order=0&thold=0 Assyrian NewYear 6758 Ceremony In Tehran] (brasheet.com) * [http://www.brasheet.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=69&mode=&order=0&thold=0 Assyrian NewYear 6758 Ceremony In Urmia] (brasheet.com)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kha b' Nisan}} [[Category:Assyrian culture]] [[Category:Spring festivals]] [[Category:Festivals in Iraq]] [[Category:New Year celebrations]] [[Category:Nisan]] [[Category:April observances]] [[Category:Festivals in Syria]] [[Category:Festivals in Iran]] [[Category:Spring (season) events in Iran]]

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
The '''Koszta Affair''' (1853) was the name applied to a diplomatic episode between the [[United States]] and the [[Austrian Empire]] involving the rights in foreign countries of new Americans who were not yet fully naturalized. ==Background== Martin Koszta, a man of [[Hungary|Hungarian]] birth, had taken part in the [[Revolutions of 1848 in Hungary|political movement of 1848-49]] for detaching Hungary from the dominion of the [[Emperor of Austria]] (of which it was part). He fled to [[Turkey]] upon the failure of that movement. After a short detention, he emigrated to the United States. In July 1852, he made a declaration under oath of his intention to become a citizen of the United States and, at the same time, renounced all allegiance to any foreign power. ==Abduction== After residing in the United States for a year and eleven months, Koszta returned to Turkey on private business. He was placed under the protection of the United States by the American consul at [[Izmir|Smyrna]] and the American [[chargé d'affaires]] ''ad interim'' at [[Istanbul|Constantinople]]. While waiting to return to the United States, Koszta was captured by Austrian officers and taken by force aboard the Austrian brig-of-war ''Huszár'' and confined in chains. United States officials protested in vain to the Turkish government and the Austrian officers. Americans learned of rumors that the prisoner was to be transported secretly to [[Trieste]]. Under instructions from the American Minister at [[Istanbul]], [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] [[Duncan Ingraham]] of the United States sloop-of-war [[USS St. Louis (1828)|''Saint Louis'']], which was then lying in Smyrna harbor, on July 2, 1853, threatened to open fire on the ''Huszar'' if Koszta was not surrendered to him by four o'clock. The Austrian [[consul general]] agreed to allow Koszta to be held by the consul general of [[France]] until some agreement with the United States was reached. ==Diplomacy== On August 29, 1853, Baron Hülsemann, the Austrian chargé d'affaires in Washington, wrote to Secretary of State [[William L. Marcy]], asking for the United States to "disavow the conduct of its agents, ... hasten to call them to a severe account, and tender to Austria a satisfaction proportionate to the outrage."{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} He said that Koszta was not a naturalized citizen of the US and had never ceased to be a citizen of Austria-Hungary. Ingraham's threat was thus in violation of international law. Marcy replied on September 26, 1853, in what is known as the Hülsemann letter. He defended the position of the United States throughout on the ground that Koszta had ceased to be a citizen of Austria even by the law of Austria. His letter said;
that Koszta when seized and imprisoned was invested with the nationality of the United States, and they had therefore the right, if they chose to exercise it, to extend their protection to him; that from [[international law]] – the only law which can be rightfully appealed to for rules in this case – Austria could derive no authority to obstruct or interfere with the United States in the exercise of this right, in effecting the liberation of Koszta; and that Captain Ingraham's interposition for his release was, under the extraordinary circumstances of the case, right and proper.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}}
The letter was published, to great enthusiasm throughout the United States. The State Department's position in relation to the status of immigrants who were not fully naturalized has been endorsed by various well-known authorities on international law. Koszta was ultimately released by Austria and allowed to return to the United States. The [[United States Congress]] passed a joint resolution of thanks to Captain Ingraham and decorated him with the [[Congressional Gold Medal]], in commemoration of his services. ==References== * {{Cite NIE|wstitle=Koszta Affair|year=1905}} * {{Cite Americana|wstitle=Koszta Affair|year=1920}} ===Further reading=== * ''Correspondence between the Secretary of State and the chargé d'affaires of Austria relative to the case of Martin Koszta'' (Washington, 1853) * Rhoades, J. F., ''History of the United States from the Compromise of 1850'' (New York, 1910) [[Category:1853 in the United States]] [[Category:1853 in the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:History of immigration to the United States]] [[Category:Austria–United States relations]] [[Category:Diplomatic incidents]] [[Category:Kidnappings]]

{{Colorsample|#A0A0A0}} (Medium colours) Leagues or championships between clubs
{{Colorsample|#D0D0D0}} (Lighter colours) Cups or tournaments between clubs |} {{TOC limit|limit=2}} This is a list of the '''[[association football]] competitions''' past and present for international teams and for club football, in individual countries and internationally. Confirmed future competitions, such as the [[4 Associations' Tournament]], are also included. The competitions are grouped by organising authority: the FIFA (international association), the six confederations (continental associations), and the federations (national associations). ==FIFA (Intercontinental competitions)== This section lists the worldwide and intercontinental competitions ruled by the [[FIFA]], by two or more confederations or by two or more federations member of different confederations. [[Image:World Map FIFA.svg|300px|right|thumb|Continental Confederations]] '''National teams''' ===Worldwide=== *[[FIFA World Cup]] *[[FIFA Women's World Cup]] *[[FIFA Confederations Cup]] *[[Football at the Summer Olympics|Summer Olympic Games]] *[[Football at the Summer Universiade|Summer Universiade]] ===Intercontinental=== *[[Artemio Franchi Trophy]] (between winners and runners-up of [[Copa America]] and [[UEFA European Championship]]) *[[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]] (defunct competition endorsed between UEFA and CONMEBOL *[[UEFA–CAF Meridian Cup]] (defunct under-18 men tournament between teams from Europe and Africa) === Invitational tournaments === Invitational tournaments are competitions that feature a cup, sometimes holding the name of the host country. The host country invites other nations to participate in the tournament. * [[Australia Bicentenary Gold Cup]] *Algeria International Tournament *[[Balkan Cup]] * [[Brazil Independence Cup]] * [[China Cup]] * [[Canada Cup (soccer)|Canada Cup]] *[[Korea Cup]] * [[Kirin Cup]] * [[Lunar New Year Cup]] *[[Nehru Cup]] *[[Nordic Football Championship]] * [[Rous Cup]] * [[Taça das Nações]] *Triangular de Oro * [[Umbro Cup]] * [[1976 U.S.A. page.title: List of fashion events in the United States

revision.comment: /* List */
revision.text:
[[File:Future Heretics Jolene Andersen.jpg|right|thumb|Future Heretics model, Jolene Andersen, 2011|300px]] This is a '''list of [[fashion week]]s, events and [[fashion show]]s''' held annually or two times a year in the [[United States]]. The list is ordered alphabetically.
== List == * [[Africa Fashion Week New York]] * [[Africa Fashion Week Houston]] * [[Dallas Fashion Week]] * [[Detroit Fashion Week]] * [[DC Fashion Week]] * [[Fashion in Film Festival]] * [[Fashion Week Cleveland]] * [[Ford Models Supermodel of the World]] * [[Glamorama (Macy's)|Glamorama]] * [[Hair Wars]] * [[Houston Fashion Week]] * [[Los Angeles Fashion Week]] ** [[Men's Fashion Week]] * [[Men's Fashion Week Los Angeles]] * [[Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Miami]] * [[Met Gala|Met Ball]] * [[Miami Fashion Week]] [[File:Milagros Schmoll3.jpg|thumb|[[Milagros Schmoll]] walks the runway at the [[Custo Barcelona]] Spring 2009 show in New York.|240px]] * [[New York Fashion Week]] (capital) ** [[Fall 2008 fashion weeks]] ** [[List of Fall 2008 New York Fashion Week fashion shows]] ** [[Men's Fashion Week]] ** [[Spring 2008 New York Fashion Week]] * [[Saint Louis Fashion Week]] * [[Omaha Fashion Week]] * [[Oklahoma City Fachion Week]] * [[Kansas City Fashion Week]] * [[Pittsburgh Fashion Week]] * [[Rip the Runway]] * [[Victoria's Secret Fashion Show]]
== See also == * [[List of fashion events]]
