revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} {{distinguish|loser (disambiguation)}} {{For|other traditions of celebrating the lunar new year|Lunar New Year}} {{Infobox holiday| |holiday_name = Losar |image = |imagesize = |caption = |nickname = Tibetan New Year
Lhochhar |observedby = [[Tibetan people|Tibetans]], [[Bhutanese people|Bhutanese]], [[Tibetan Buddhist]]s and certain ethnic groups in [[Nepal]] |date2012 = 23 January, [[Dragon (zodiac)|Dragon]] |date2013 = 10 February, [[Snake (zodiac)|Snake]] |date2014 = 31 January, [[Horse (zodiac)|Horse]] |date2015 = 19 February, [[Goat (zodiac)|Sheep]] |date2016 = 9 February, [[Monkey (zodiac)|Monkey]] |date2017 = 27 February, [[Rooster (zodiac)|Bird/Rooster]]{{efn-ua|In the Tibetan and Gurung zodiac, the bird is the seventh and tenth zodiac, respectively, and thus will be considered the "Year of the Bird". The Gurungs celebrated the "Year of the Bird" in December 2016.{{cite web|url=http://ahmc.ngalso.net/2014/01/28/tibetan-astrology-table-of-year-animal-element-2/?lang=en |title=Tibetan Astrology – Table of Year-Animal-Element | Albagnano Healing Meditation Centre |website=Ahmc.ngalso.net |date=2014-01-28 |accessdate=2017-01-21}} The Tamang celebrated Sonam Losar - The Year of the [[Rooster (zodiac)|Rooster]] on January 29, 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.timeanddate.com/holidays/nepal/2017 |title=Holidays and observances in Nepal in 2017 |website=Timeanddate.com |date=2016-12-31 |accessdate=2017-01-21}}}} |date2018 = 16 February, [[Dog (zodiac)|Dog]] |date2019 = 5 February, [[Pig (zodiac)|Boar/Pig/Deer]]{{efn-ua|In the Tibetan zodiac, the boar is the ninth zodiac and thus will be considered the "Year of the Boar". In the Gurung zodiac, the deer is the twelfth zodiac and thus will be considered the "Year of the Deer". The Gurungs will celebrate the "Year of the Deer" in December 2018.{{cite web|url=http://ecs.com.np/culture/tamu-gurung-losar-festival |title=Tamu (Gurung) Losar Festival | Culture | ECSNEPAL - The Nepali Way |website=Ecs.com.np |date=2010-07-11 |accessdate=2017-01-21}}}} |date2020 = 25 January, [[Rat (zodiac)|Rat]] |date2021 = |frequency= Annual |duration=15 days |type =Asian festival |longtype = [[Tibetan culture]], [[Tibetan Buddhist]], [[new year]] |significance = |relatedto = Other [[Lunar New Year|lunisolar new year]] festivals in Asia }} {{Tibetan Buddhism}} '''Losar''' ({{Bo|t=ལོ་གསར་|w=lo-gsar}}; "new year"William D. Crump, "Losar" in ''Encyclopedia of New Year's Holidays Worldwide'' (McFarland & Co.: 2008), pp. 237-38.) is a festival in [[Tibetan Buddhism]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/buddhism/holydays/losar.shtml |title=Buddhism: Losar |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=September 8, 2004}} The holiday is celebrated on various dates depending on location ([[Tibet]], [[Nepal]] and [[Bhutan]]) and tradition.Peter Glen Harle, [https://books.google.com/books?id=urbWAAAAMAAJ Thinking with Things: Objects and Identity among Tibetans in the Twin Cities] (Ph.D dissertation: [[Indiana University]], 2003), p. 132: "In Tibet, Nepal, Bhutan, and other areas where Tibetan Buddhism is practiced, the dates for Losar are often calculated locally, and often vary from region.".William D. Crump, ''Encyclopedia of New Year's Holidays Worldwide'' (McFarland & Co.: 2008), pp. 237: ""Different traditions have observed Losar on different dates." The holiday is a [[new year]]'s festival, celebrated on the first day of the [[lunisolar]] [[Tibetan calendar]], which corresponds to a date in February or March in the [[Gregorian calendar]]. In 2018, the new year commenced on the 16th of February and celebrations will run until the 18th of the same month. It also commenced the Year of the Male Earth Dog.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?ei=DNU_WvDeK4PGmQGEjqaIAw&q=Losar+2018&oq=Losar+2018&gs_l=psy-ab.3..0l3.10631.11240.0.11623.5.5.0.0.0.0.90.395.5.5.0....0...1c.1.64.psy-ab..0.5.392...0i67k1j0i22i30k1.0.Jttk7jiUiVg|title=Losar 2018 - Google Search|author=|date=|website=www.google.com|accessdate=April 5, 2018}} The variation of the festival in Nepal is called '''''Lhochhar''''' and is observed about eight weeks earlier than the Tibetan Losar.[https://books.google.com/books?id=SB9mAAAAMAAJ Tibetan Borderlands: PIATS 2003]: ''Proceedings of the International Association of Tibetan Studies'', Oxford, 2003, p. 121: "Yet though their Lhochhar is observed about eight weeks earlier than the Tibetan Losar, the festival is clearly borrowed, and their practice of Buddhism comes increasingly in a Tibetan idiom." ==History== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 135-S-16-20-16, Tibetexpedition, Neujahrsfest Lhasa.jpg|thumb|right|Losar celebration in Lhasa, 1938]] Losar predates the arrival of Buddhism in Tibet and has its roots in a winter [[incense]]-burning custom of the [[Bon religion]]. During the reign of the ninth Tibetan king, Pude Gungyal (617-698), it is said that this custom merged with a [[harvest festival]] to form the annual Loser festival. The [[14th Dalai Lama]] (1998: p. 233) frames the importance of consulting the [[Nechung Oracle]] for Losar: {{Quotation|For hundreds of years now, it has been traditional for the Dalai Lama, and the Government, to consult Nechung during the New Year festivals.Gyatso, Tenzin (1988). ''Freedom in Exile: the Autobiography of the Dalai Lama of Tibet'' (rev. ed.: [[Abacus Books]], London. {{ISBN|0-349-11111-1}}}} [[Tenzin Wangyal]] (2002: p.xvii) frames his experience of Tibetan cultural practice of Losar in relation to elemental celebrations and offerings to [[Nāga]] (Tibetan: ''Klu''): {{Quotation|During Losar, the Tibetan celebration of the new year, we did not drink champagne to celebrate. Instead, we went to the local spring to perform a ritual of gratitude. We made offerings to the ''nagas'', the water spirits who activated the water element in the area. We made smoke offerings to the local spirits associated with the natural world around us. Beliefs and behaviors like ours evolved long ago and are often seen as primitive in the West. But they are not only projections of human fears onto the natural world, as some anthropologists and historians suggest. Our way of relating to the elements originated in the direct experiences by our sages and common people of the sacred nature of the external and internal elements. We call these elements earth, water, fire, air, and space.[[Tenzin Wangyal Rinpoche]] (2002). ''Healing with Form, Energy, and Light''. Ithaca, New York: [[Snow Lion Publications]]. {{ISBN|1-55939-176-6}}}} [[File:Gumpa.jpg|thumb|right|340px|The [[Gumpa dance]] being performed in [[Lachung]] during the [[Buddhist festival]] of Losar]] ==Practice== Losar is celebrated for 15 days, with the main celebrations on the first three days. On the first day of Losar, a beverage called ''changkol'' is made from ''[[chhaang]]'' (a Tibetan cousin of [[beer]]). The second day of Losar is known as King's Losar ''(gyalpo losar)''. Losar is traditionally preceded by the five-day practice of [[Vajrakilaya]]. Because the [[Uyghurs]] adopted the [[Chinese calendar]], and the Mongols and Tibetans adopted the Uyghur calendar,{{cite book | title = Tibetan and Buddhist Studies: Commemorating the 200th Anniversary of the Birth of Alexander Csoma De Koros|volume=2| publisher = University of California Press | year = 1984 | isbn = 9789630535731 | first = Louis | last = Ligeti | pages = 344}} Losar occurs near or on the same day as the [[Chinese New Year]] and the [[Tsagaan Sar|Mongolian New Year]], but the traditions of Losar are unique to Tibet, and predate both Indian and Chinese influences. Originally, ancient celebrations of Losar occurred solely on the [[winter solstice]], and was only moved to coincide with the Chinese and Mongolian New Year by a leader of the [[Gelug]] school of Buddhism.{{cite book | title = Encyclopedia of Religion and Ethics, Part 10|publisher = Kessinger Publishing | year = 2003 | isbn = 9780766136823 | first = James | last = Hastings | pages = 892}} Prior to the [[Battle of Chamdo|Chinese occupation of Tibet]] in 1950, Losar began with a morning ritual ceremony at [[Namgyal Monastery]], led by the [[Dalai Lama]] and other high-ranking [[lama]]s, with government officials participating, to honor the [[Dharmapala]] (dharma-protector) [[Palden Lhamo]].[[J. Gordon Melton]], "Losar" in ''Religious Celebrations: An Encyclopedia of Holidays, Festivals, Solemn Observances, and Spiritual Commemorations'', Vol. 1 (ABC-CLIO), 2011), pp. 530-31. After the Dalai Lama was exiled, many monasteries were dissolved during the [[Cultural Revolution]]. Since that time, Tibetan Buddhism practice in Tibet has been somewhat restored, and "Losar is now celebrated, though without the former ceremonies surrounding the person of the Dalai Lama." In Tibet, various customs are associated with the holiday: {{quote|Families prepare for ''Losar'' some days in advance by thoroughly cleaning their homes; decorating with fragrant flowers and their walls with auspicious signs painted in flour such as the sun, moon, or a reversed [[swastika]]; and preparing [[Cedrus deodara|cedar]], [[rhododendron]], and [[juniper]] branches for burning as incense. Debts are settled, quarrels are resolved, new clothes are acquired, and special foods such as ''kapse'' (fried twists) are made. A favorite drink is ''[[Chhaang|chang]]'' (barley beer) which is served warm. Because the words "sheep's head" and "beginning of the year" sound similar in Tibetan, it is customary to fashion a sheep's head from colored butter as a decoration. Another traditional decoration that symbolizes a good harvest is the ''phyemar'' ("five-grain bucket"), a bucket with a wooden board that creates two vertical halves within. This bucket is filled with ''zanba'' (also known as ''tsamba'', roasted ''qingke'' barley flour) and barley seeds, then decorated with barley ears and colored butter.}} Losar customs in Bhutan are similar to, but distinct from, customs in neighboring Tibet.James Mayer, [http://www.festival.si.edu/blog/2013/losar-community-building-and-the-bhutanese-new-year/ Losar: Community Building and the Bhutanese New Year] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170228080558/http://www.festival.si.edu/blog/2013/losar-community-building-and-the-bhutanese-new-year/ |date=February 28, 2017 }}, [[Smithsonian Folklife Festival]], [[Smithsonian Institution]] (February 15, 2013). Modern celebration of the holiday began in Bhutan in 1637, when [[Shabdrung Ngawang Namgyal]] commemorated the completion of the [[Punakha Dzong]] with an inaugural ceremony, in which "Bhutanese came from all over the country to bring offerings of produce from their various regions, a tradition that is still reflected in the wide variety of foods consumed during the ritual Losar meals." Traditional foods consumed on the occasion include [[sugarcane]] and [[green banana]]s, which are considered auspicious. In Bhutan, picnicking, dancing, singing, [[darts|dart-playing]], archery (see [[archery in Bhutan]]), and the giving of offerings are all traditions. ==Dates== The [[Tibetan calendar]] is a [[lunisolar calendar]]. Losar is celebrated on the first through third days of the first [[lunar month]]. {| class="wikitable" |- ![[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian Year]] ! Year of Rabjung 60-year Cycle ![[Tibetan calendar|Tibetan Year]] !Losar Date*** !Gender, Element, and Animal |- |2008 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 22||2135 |February 7 |Male Earth Mouse/[[Rat (zodiac)|Rat]]** |- |2009 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 23||2136 |February 25 |Female Earth [[Ox (zodiac)|Ox]]{{cite web|url=http://www.kalacakra.org/calendar/kcal.htm |title=Kālacakra Calendar |website=Kalacakra.org |date=2013-07-27 |accessdate=2017-01-21}} |- |2010 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 24||2137 |February 14 |Male Iron [[Tiger (zodiac)|Tiger]]{{cite web |url=http://jewelheart.org/calendar/february.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308130130/http://www.jewelheart.org/calendar/february.html |archivedate=March 8, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} |- |2011 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 25||2138 |March 5 |Female Iron Hare/[[Rabbit (zodiac)|Rabbit]]**{{cite web|url=http://www.tibet-info.net/www/Losar-Nouvel-An-tibetain-en-2011.html?lang=fr |title=Losar, Nouvel An tibétain en 2011 : année 2138 du Lièvre de Fer |website=Tibet-info.net |date= |accessdate=2017-01-21}} |- |2012 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 26||2139 |February 22 |Male Water [[Dragon (zodiac)|Dragon]] |- |2013 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 27||2140 |February 11 |Female Water [[Snake (zodiac)|Snake]] |- |2014 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 28||2141 |March 2 |Male Wood [[Horse (zodiac)|Horse]] |- |2015 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 29||2142 |February 18/19 |Female Wood Sheep/[[Goat (zodiac)|Goat]]** |- |2016 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 30||2143 |February 9 {{cite web|title=Tibetan Medical and Astrological Institute|url=http://www.men-tsee-khang.org/calendar|website=Tibetan Medical and Astrological Institute|accessdate=January 27, 2016}} |Male Fire [[Monkey (zodiac)|Monkey]] |- |2017 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 31||2144 |February 27 |Female Fire Bird/[[Rooster (zodiac)|Rooster]] |- |'''2018''' |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 32||'''2145''' |'''February 16''' |'''Male Earth [[Dog (zodiac)|Dog]]''' |- |2019 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 33||2146 |February 5 |Female Earth [[Pig (zodiac)|Pig]]/Boar** |- |2020 |''rab byung'' 17 ''lo'' 34||2147 |February 24 |Male Iron Mouse/[[Rat (zodiac)|Rat]]** |} : * Note: [[Tibetan calendar#Years|Rabjung]] (Wylie: rab byung) is the name of the 60-year cycle of the Tibetan calendar that started in 1027 CE, and is currently in its 17th cycle. : ** Note: These year names have more than one translation into English with different terms used by different groups. : *** Note: Losar is celebrated by some international communities at more or less the same time it is celebrated in Asia. For example, for a year when Losar starts on February 1 in Asia time zones, it may be celebrated by some in United States time zones on January 31. Losar celebrations are normally for three days. == Notes == {{notelist-ua}} ==See also== *[[Galdan Namchot]] *[[Lunar New Year]] *[[Nepali calendar]] *[[Tibetan astrology]] *[[Tibetan calendar]] *Celebrations of Lunar New Year in other parts of Asia: ** [[Chinese New Year]] ''(Spring Festival)'' ** [[Korean New Year]] ''(Seollal)'' ** [[Japanese New Year]] ''(Shōgatsu)'' ** [[Tsagaan Sar|Mongolian New Year]] ''(Tsagaan Sar)'' ** [[Tết|Vietnamese New Year]] ''(Tết)'' *Similar Asian Lunisolar New Year celebrations that occur in April: **[[Thingyan|Burmese New Year]] ''(Thingyan)'' **[[Cambodian New Year]] ''(Chaul Chnam Thmey)'' **[[Songkran (Lao)|Lao New Year]] ''(Pii Mai)'' **[[Sinhalese New Year|Sri Lankan New Year]] ''(Aluth Avuruddu)'' **[[Songkran (Thailand)|Thai New Year]] ''(Songkran)'' ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Commons category}} {{Portal bar|Tibet|Holidays}} {{Portal bar|Nepal|Holidays}} {{Portal bar|Bhutan|Holidays}} [[Category:Nepalese culture]] [[Category:Bhutanese culture]] [[Category:Public holidays in Nepal]] [[Category:Public holidays in Bhutan]] [[Category:New Year celebrations]] [[Category:Tibetan festivals]] [[Category:Religious festivals in Nepal]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian January observances]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian February observances]] [[Category:Buddhist holidays]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian March observances]] [[Category:Observances set by the Tibetan calendar]] [[Category:Religious festivals in Tibet]] [[Category:Religious festivals in India]] [[Category:Festivals in Nepal]] [[Category:Festivals in Bhutan]]

revision.text:
{{selfref|Not to be confused with [[Mpack (unix)]], the command-line utility for manipulating [[MIME]]-encoded messages, or the [http://mplapack.sourceforge.net/ MPACK] [[arbitrary-precision arithmetic]] [[LAPACK]] library.}} {{Infobox software | name = MPack | title = MPack | logo = <!-- [[File: ]] --> | screenshot = <!-- [[File: ]] --> | caption = | collapsible = | author = | developer = | released = December 2006 <!-- {{Start date|2006|12|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | discontinued = | latest release version = | latest release date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | frequently updated = <!-- DO NOT include this parameter unless you know what it does --> | programming language = [[PHP]] | operating system = | platform = | size = | language = | status = | genre = Malware kit | license = Proprietary | website = }} In [[computer security]], '''MPack''' is a [[PHP]]-based [[malware]] kit produced by Russian [[Software cracking|crackers]]. The first version was released in December 2006. Since then a new version is thought to have been released roughly every month. It is thought to have been used to infect up to 160,000 PCs with [[keylogger|keylogging software]]. In August 2007 it was believed to have been used in an attack on the web site of the [[Bank of India]] which originated from the [[Russian Business Network]].
Unusual for such kits, MPack is sold as commercial software (costing $500 to $1,000 US), and is provided by its developers with technical support and regular updates of the [[vulnerability (computer science)|software vulnerabilities]] it exploits. Modules are sold by the developers containing new exploits. These cost between $50 and $150 US depending on how severe the exploit is. The developers also charge to make the scripts and executables undetectable by [[antivirus software]].
The server-side software in the kit is able to customize attacks to a variety of [[web browser]]s including [[Microsoft Internet Explorer]], [[Mozilla Firefox]] and [[Opera (web browser)|Opera]]. MPack generally works by being loaded in an [[HTML element#Frames|IFrame]] attached to the bottom of a defaced website. When a user visits the page, MPack sends a script that loads in the IFrame and determines if any vulnerabilities in the browser or operating system can be exploited. If it finds any, it will exploit them and store various statistics for future reference.
Included with the server is a management console, which allows the attacker deploying the software to view statistics about the computers that have been infected, including what web browsers they were using and what countries their connections originated from.
==See also== * [[Exploit (computer security)|Exploit]] * [[Exploit kit]] * [[Trojan horse (computing)]] * [[Spyware]] * [[Botnet]] * [[Computer virus]] * [[Backdoor (computing)]]
== References ==
* {{cite web| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/6221306.stm| title=Hackers target 'legitimate' sites| publisher=BBC| date=2007-06-20| accessdate=2007-06-26}} * {{cite web| url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/mpack-packed-full-badness| title=MPack, Packed Full of Badness| publisher=Symantec| date=2007-05-27| accessdate=2007-06-26}} * {{cite web| url=http://blogs.pandasoftware.com/blogs/images/PandaLabs/2007/05/11/MPack.pdf| title=PandaLabs Report: MPack uncovered| publisher=PandaLabs| date=2007-05-11| accessdate=2007-07-04}} * {{cite web| url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/07/03/mpack_reloaded/| title=MPack malware exposes cheapskate web hosts| publisher=The Register| date=2007-07-04| accessdate=2007-07-04}} * {{cite web| url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/07/23/mpack_developer_interview| title=Interview with MPack developer| publisher=The Register| date=2007-07-23| accessdate=2007-07-23}} * {{cite web| url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/securityfix/2007/10/mapping_the_russian_business_n.html| title=Mapping the Russian Business Network| author=Brian Krebs| publisher=Washington Post blogs| date=2007-10-13| accessdate=2007-10-14}} * {{cite web |url = http://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?command=viewArticleBasic&articleId=9033999 |title = Bank of India site hacked, serves up 22 exploits |author = Gregg Keizer |publisher = Computer World |date = 2007-09-30 |accessdate = 2007-10-14 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071014194155/http://computerworld.com/action/article.do?command=viewArticleBasic&articleId=9033999 |archivedate = 2007-10-14 |df = }}

revision.text:
Within [[Marxist]] theory, modern warfare is described as existing as result of [[Capitalism]]. Marxist theory states that all modern wars are caused by competition for resources and markets between great ([[Imperialism|imperialist]]) powers, claiming these wars are a natural result of the [[free market]] and a [[Social class|class system]].<ref name="Einde_2007">{{cite web |url=http://www.marxists.org/archive/mandel/1955/08/imp-crit.html |title=The Marxist Theory of Imperialism and its Critics |first=Einde |last=O'Callaghan |publisher=[[Marxists Internet Archive]] |date=25 October 2007 |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref>
== Theory == The Marxist theory includes the belief that war will only disappear once a Communist [[world revolution]] has occurred, which over-throws free markets and class systems.<ref name="Einde_2007"/>
=== Rosa Luxemburg === Marxist philosopher [[Rosa Luxemburg]] theorized that [[imperialism]] was the result of capitalist countries needing new [[Market (economics)|market]]s. Expansion of the [[means of production]] is only possible if there is a corresponding growth in [[consumer demand]]. Since the workers in a [[capitalist economy]] would be unable to fill the demand, producers must expand into non-capitalist markets to find consumers for their goods, hence driving imperialism.<ref name="Einde_2007"/>
=== Lenin === [[Lenin]] expanded upon Marx’s ideas, providing an analysis of what Lenin described as "[[monopoly capitalism]]". In his theory, Lenin suggested that as capitalism developed as a system, monopoly capitalism was the highest stage of its development. According to Lenin, “imperialism is capitalism when “the formation of international capitalist monopolies will share the world among themselves and the territorial division of the whole world among the greatest capitalist powers is completed”.<ref>Lenin, V.I. (1996) ‘Imperialism: the Highest Stage of Capitalism’, London, Pluto Press.</ref>
In this way Lenin is suggesting that capitalist powers will cause wars with weaker nations to increase their holding of monopoly capital. As capitalism develops, its natural progression is for core capitalist nations to exploit those on the periphery through imperialist wars in search of new markets and resources. Lenin’s theory provided the origins of "[[world systems theory]]".<ref>Hobden, S. and Wyn Jones, R. (2008) ‘Marxist Theories of International Relations’, in Baylis, J., Smith, S., and Owens, P. (2008) (Eds) ‘The Globalization of World Politics. An introduction to international relations’, New York, Oxford University Press, p.147</ref>
== See also == * [[Marxist philosophy]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Causes of war]] [[Category:Marxist theory]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} [[File:Middlewich Folk and Boat - Eliza Carthy.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Eliza Carthy and the Ratcatchers (2005)]]
The '''Middlewich Folk and Boat Festival''' takes place in June in [[Middlewich]], [[Cheshire]], [[England]]. The festival builds on the town's [[industry|industrial]] heritage in which [[canal]] [[Narrowboat|boats]] were used to move [[coal]] and other raw materials in the town for the production of [[salt]], and then move the salt out of town, either for use directly, or as a raw material in the manufacture of chemicals such as [[chlorine]] and [[Sodium carbonate|soda ash]].
The Middlewich Folk and Boat festival is now firmly established on the folk circuit and it is estimated that 30,000 people visit the town during the festival weekend, along with 400 boats. The festival was originally organised by members of [[the Middlewich Paddies]], and taken over by the local council in 2011 when the original committee were unable to continue with the event.<ref>{{cite web|title=Middlewich Folk and Boat Festival saved from sinking by town council|url=http://www.crewechronicle.co.uk/news/local-news/middlewich-folk-boat-festival-saved-5609423}}</ref> In 2008, the festival was declared among the top three folk festivals in England by Guardian Online.<ref>{{cite web|title=Folk on the water at top music festival|work=icCheshireOnline|date=7 May 2008|accessdate=2008-05-07|url=http://iccheshireonline.icnetwork.co.uk/crewechronicle/news/tm_headline=folk-on-the-water-at-top-music-festival&method=full&objectid=20870700&siteid=50020-name_page.html}}</ref>
==History== The festival has been held since 1990. It was cancelled in 2001 because of [[Foot and Mouth disease]].
==The festival== Since 1990 there has been an annual [[English folk music#Folk Music|folk]] [[music]] and [[Narrowboat|(canal) boat]] [[Music festivals|festival]], which is now highly regarded on the folk circuit<ref>{{cite news|title=10 top folk festivals|work=Guardian Online|date=23 April 2008|accessdate=2008-05-07|url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2008/apr/23/folkfestivals.uk?page=all | location=London | first=Peter | last=Dominiczak}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Middlewich Folk and Boat Festival |work=The Mudcat Cafe |accessdate=2008-05-07 |url=http://www.mudcat.org/thread.cfm?threadid=88138&messages=18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006021745/http://www.mudcat.org/thread.cfm?threadid=88138&messages=18 |archivedate=6 October 2007 |df= }}</ref> with visitors coming into the town from all over the UK. During this festival artists appear at venues throughout the town, whilst [[Morris dance|Morris Dancing]] and Craft Stalls also featured. The boating festival centres on the [[Trent and Mersey Canal]]. The main venues where people and boats converge are the Big Lock and Kings Lock, public houses next to locks of the same name on the Trent and Mersey canal.
==Artistes== [[File:Folk and Boat Poster 2014.png|thumbnail|alt=Poster depicting artistes Ade Edmondson & The Bad Shepherds, The Men They Couldn't Hang, Hat Fitz & Cara, The Peace Artistes, Emma Stevens, Brian McCombe Band, Moulettes, Headsticks, [[Merry Hell]], Jaipur Kawa Brass Band, Africa Entsha, Jessica Rhodes |2014 Poster showing artistes]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = Not Tonight | image = Not_Tonight_Video_Game_Logo.jpg | developer = PanicBarn | publisher = No More Robots | released = '''Microsoft Windows'''
August 17, 2018 | genre = [[Adventure game|Adventure]], [[Role-playing video game|role-playing]] | director = Tim Constant | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] }} '''''Not Tonight''''' is an [[Role-playing video game|role-playing]] [[adventure game]] by British studio PanicBarn, released for [[Microsoft Windows]] in August 2018. Set in an [[alternate timeline]] shortly after the United Kingdom's vote to [[Brexit|leave the European Union]], the player takes the role of a European-born immigrant who must survive under a far-right British government, working as a bouncer across various venues and earning enough keep to avoid deportation. Along the way, the player must make decisions on whether to change the course of events or remain complicit with the new administration. == Gameplay == The gameplay of ''Not Tonight'' is based on the responsibilities of a bouncer, working for Albion ([[England]]) as a citizen of European heritage. As a bouncer, the player must analyse various parts of the guests license checking whether they are under age, provided fraudulent information or have an incorrectly matching photograph. As the game progresses, the player must undertake additional measures as requested by larger venues or by the state. This includes: stopping various nationalities from entering, those who wear certain clothing, individuals who are not on the guest list, people without tickets and various other rules as gameplay becomes more challenging. Additionally, the player can also accept bribes which will gain immediate money at the expense of losing social credit score. Failing to pass a game will lower credit score. A loss of social credit can prevent the player from gaining more jobs and damage their progress. After every mission, the player returns to their flat to interact with characters, pay any outstanding rent and to purchase any items that they may need. While playing the game, the player must make decisions which will affect the story through various characters that can be encountered. == Plot == The game starts with an explosion at a public event with a destroyed [[London Eye]] on the Thames. During the rule of the far right Albion First party, which later breaks from a conservative coalition to form its own government via election rigging, the player is working as a bouncer taking tickets at the British Museum of History celebration event until it is blown up. Soon after the explosion, the game goes back an entire year to when the character must earn enough to prevent his deportation and eviction. The player is referred to as Person of European Heritage #112. The player must spend the year leading to the ultimate events using the BouncR app via the government issued phone to gain employment, all while being monitored by presiding officer, Jupp. The player can make various decision to either support the government or the resistance. == Reception == Not tonight received mixed to positive reviews. Review aggregator [[Metacritic]] has a total review score of 71/100, based on several submissions. Wccftech gave it a positive score of 80. PC Gamer later giving it 71. Screen Rant gave an independent review of 4 out of 5 stars. Trusted Reviews summarized "''Not Tonight'' proves that the ''Papers, Please'' formula can work in a less Soviet setting, but the experience is slightly diminished by the transplant. Yet its eccentricities remain endearing, with characters, landscapes and a haunting sound of muffled music that will be rambling around my skull for a little while yet."{{Cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/not-tonight|title=Not Tonight - PC|last=|first=|date=Aug 17, 2018|website=[[Metacritic]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://screenrant.com/not-tonight-review/|title=Not Tonight Review: A Darkly Comic Look At A Dangerous Timeline|last=|first=|date=Aug 17, 2018|website=Screen Rant|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Many reviewers have mentioned the likeness of the game to that of ''[[Papers, Please]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.trustedreviews.com/reviews/not-tonight|title=Not Tonight Review|last=|first=|date=|website=Trusted Reviews|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/03/29/not-tonight-post-brexit-bouncer-game/?guccounter=1|title='Not Tonight' makes you a bouncer in post-Brexit Britain|last=|first=|date=|website=Engadget (UK)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:2018 video games]] [[Category:Adventure games]] [[Category:Role-playing games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Video games set in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Video games set in the 2040s]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]] [[Category:Brexit]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox song | name = One Tree Hill | cover = One_tree_hill_cover.jpg | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[U2]] | album = [[The Joshua Tree]] | B-side = *"[[Bullet the Blue Sky]]" *"[[Running to Stand Still]]" | released = {{start date|1988|03|7|df=y}}<ref name="Sams">{{cite web|first= Aaron |last= Sams |first2= Harry |last2= Kantas |title= U2 – "One Tree Hill" Single |publisher= U2songs.com |accessdate= 25 May 2016 |url= http://www.u2songs.com/discography/u2_one_tree_hill_single}}</ref> | format = * [[Gramophone record#Formats|7-inch 45{{nbsp}}rpm]] * [[cassette single]] | recorded = July 1986 – January 1987 | studio = [[Windmill Lane Studios]] (Dublin) | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] | length = {{Duration|m=5|s=23}} | label = * [[Island Records|Island]] * [[Festival Records|Festival]] | composer = U2 | lyricist = [[Bono]] | producer = * [[Daniel Lanois]] * [[Brian Eno]] | prev_title = [[In God's Country]] | prev_year = 1987 | next_title = [[Desire (U2 song)|Desire]] | next_year = 1988 }} "'''One Tree Hill'''" is a song by Irish [[rock music|rock]] band [[U2]] and the ninth track on their 1987 album ''[[The Joshua Tree]]''. In March 1988, it was released as the fourth single from the album in New Zealand and Australia, while "[[In God's Country]]" was released as the fourth single in North America.<ref name="Sams">{{cite web|first= Aaron |last= Sams |first2= Harry |last2= Kantas |title= U2 – "One Tree Hill" Single |publisher= U2songs.com |accessdate= 25 May 2016 |url= http://www.u2songs.com/discography/u2_one_tree_hill_single}}</ref> The release charted at number one on the [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand|New Zealand Singles Chart]].
The track was written in memory of Greg Carroll, a [[Māori people|Māori]] man the band first met in [[Auckland]] during [[the Unforgettable Fire Tour]] in 1984. He became very close friends with lead singer [[Bono]] and later served as a [[road crew|roadie]] for the group. Carroll was killed in July 1986 in a motorcycle accident in Dublin. Following the [[Tangihanga|tangi]] funeral in New Zealand, Bono wrote the lyrics to "One Tree Hill" in Carroll's memory. The lyrics reflect Bono's thoughts at the tangi and during his first night in New Zealand when Carroll took him up Auckland's [[One Tree Hill (New Zealand)|One Tree Hill]]. They also pay homage to Chilean singer-songwriter and activist [[Víctor Jara]]. Musically, the song was developed in a [[jam session]] with producer [[Brian Eno]]. The vocals were recorded in a single take, as Bono felt incapable of singing them a second time.
"One Tree Hill" was received favourably by critics, who variously described it as "a soft, haunting benediction",<ref name="Pond" /> "a remarkable musical centrepiece",<ref name="Hogg" /> and a celebration of life.<ref name="Graham" /> U2 delayed performing the song on the [[Joshua Tree Tour]] in 1987 because of Bono's fears over his emotional state. After its live debut on the tour's third leg and an enthusiastic reaction from audiences, the song was played occasionally for the rest of the tour and semi-regularly during the [[Lovetown Tour]] of 1989–1990. It has appeared only sporadically since then, and most renditions were performed in New Zealand. Performances in November 2010 on the [[U2 360° Tour]] were dedicated to the miners who died in the [[Pike River Mine disaster]]. During [[the Joshua Tree Tour 2017]] to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the album, "One Tree Hill" was performed at each show.
==Inspiration, writing, and recording== {{Quote box|quote="They took me up to the top of a place called [[One Tree Hill (New Zealand)|One Tree Hill]], where a single tree stands at the top of the mount, like some stark Japanese painting, and we looked around at [[Auckland|this city]] that's made by craters of volcanoes. I remember it so vividly, I think, because it meant something to me about my own freedom."|source=—Bono<ref name="U2157" /> |width=25% |align=left |style=padding:8px;}}
[[U2]] first visited Australia and New Zealand in 1984 to open [[The Unforgettable Fire Tour]].<ref>de la Parra (2003), pp. 52–54</ref> After a 24-hour flight into [[Auckland]], lead singer [[Bono]] was unable to adjust to the time difference between New Zealand and Europe. He left his hotel room during the night and met some people who showed him around the city. Greg Carroll was part of that group: he had met U2's production manager Steve Iredale and been offered a job helping the band for their upcoming concert on account of Greg's experience with local rock bands. They ended up taking Bono up [[One Tree Hill (New Zealand)|One Tree Hill (Maungakiekie)]], one of the highest – and more spiritually significant to [[Māori people]] – of [[Auckland volcanic field|Auckland's largest volcanoes]].<ref>Stokes (2005), p. 74</ref><ref name="Koot">Kootnikoff (2010), p. 46</ref> Greg worked as a stage hand gently stopping people getting on stage, and was described as "this very helpful fellah running around the place".<ref name="U2157">McCormick (2006), p. 157</ref> U2's manager [[Paul McGuinness]] thought Carroll was so helpful that he should accompany the band for the remainder of the tour.<ref name="Stokes">Stokes (2005), p. 75</ref> The group helped him obtain a passport, and he subsequently joined them on the road in Australia and the United States as their assistant.<ref name="Koot" /><ref name="U2177">McCormick (2006), p. 177</ref> He became very close friends with Bono and his wife [[Ali Hewson]], and following the conclusion of the tour, he worked for U2 in [[Dublin]].<ref name="U2157" /><ref name="Stokes" />
[[File:One Tree Hill Auckland in the 1990s.jpg|thumb|[[One Tree Hill (New Zealand)|One Tree Hill]] pictured in 1996. The tree was later removed by authorities in 2000, six years after being chainsawed by a Māori activist.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/993105.stm |work=BBC News |title=One Tree Hill loses its tree |date=26 October 2000 |accessdate=25 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61y3MG7HE?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/993105.stm |archivedate=25 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>|alt=]]
On 3 July 1986,<ref name="Parra86">de la Parra (2003), p. 78</ref> just before the start of the recording sessions for ''[[The Joshua Tree]]'', Carroll was killed in a motorcycle accident while on a courier run. A car had pulled in front of him, and unable to stop in the rain, Carroll struck the side of the car and was killed instantly.<ref name="Stokes" /> The event shocked the entire band; drummer [[Larry Mullen, Jr.]] said, "his death really rocked us – it was the first time anyone in our working circle had been killed."<ref name="U2177" /> Guitarist [[the Edge]] said, "Greg was like a member of the family, but the fact that he had come under our wing and had travelled so far from home to be in Dublin to work with us made it all the more difficult to deal with."<ref name="U2178">McCormick (2006), p. 178</ref> Bassist [[Adam Clayton]] described it as "a very sobering moment", saying, "it inspired the awareness that there are more important things than rock 'n' roll. That your family, your friends and indeed the other members of the band – you don't know how much time you've got left with them."<ref name="Stokes" /><ref name="U2178" /> Bono said, "it was a devastating blow. He was doing me a favour. He was taking my bike home."<ref name="Stokes" /> He later commented, "it brought gravitas to the recording of ''The Joshua Tree''. We had to fill the hole in our heart with something very, very large indeed, we loved him so much."<ref name="U2178" /> Accompanied by Bono, Ali, Mullen, and other members of the U2 organisation, Carroll's body was flown back to New Zealand and buried in the [[Tangihanga|traditional Māori manner]] at Kai-iwi Marae near [[Whanganui]], Carroll's hometown.<ref name="Stokes" /><ref name="Parra86" /> Bono sang "[[Let It Be (song)|Let It Be]]" and "[[Knockin' on Heaven's Door]]" for him at the funeral.<ref name="Parra86" />
Shortly after returning to Dublin, Bono wrote lyrics for a song about the funeral that he titled "One Tree Hill" after the hill he remembered from his visit to Auckland in 1984.<ref name="Parra86" /> The music was developed early in the recording sessions for ''The Joshua Tree''. The Edge said, "We were jamming with [[Brian Eno|Brian [Eno]]]. He was playing keyboards ... we just got this groove going, and this part began to come through. It's almost [[highlife]], although it's not African at all ... the sound was for me at that time a very elaborate one. I would never have dreamt of using a sound like that before then, but it just felt right, and I went with it."<ref name="Hare">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.hotpress.com/archive/4269254.html |title=The Secret History of 'The Joshua Tree' |magazine=[[Hot Press]] |first=Colm |last=O'Hare |date=28 November 2007 |accessdate=27 April 2011 |volume=31 |issue=23 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62tpK3dK8?url=http://www.hotpress.com/archive/4269254.html |archivedate= 2 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Bono recorded his vocals in a single take, as he felt that he could not sing the lyrics a second time.<ref name="Phantom">{{cite video |title=Interview with Paul McGuinness |people=[[Paul McGuinness]]; John Caddel |publisher=[[Phantom FM]]. Dublin Rock Radio Ltd. |location=Dublin |medium=Radio broadcast |time=5:50 |date=9 December 2007}}</ref> The Edge used a [[Bond Electraglide]] guitar to play a solo with a "heavy [[Distortion (music)|fuzz]]" sound at the end of the song.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.guitarworld.com/u2s-edge-discusses-gear-and-joshua-tree-1987-guitar-world-interview|title=The Leading Edge: U2's Minimal Guitarist Makes It Seem So Easy, But That's Only Because Maximal Thought Went Into It.|magazine=[[Guitar World]]|first=Joe|last=Bosso|date=July 1987|pages=50+|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> Three musicians from [[Toronto]]—Dick, Paul and Adele Armin—recorded string pieces for the song in Grant Avenue Studio in [[Hamilton, Ontario]]. In a six-hour phone call with the Edge, and under the supervision of producer [[Daniel Lanois]], the Armins used "sophisticated 'electro-acoustic' string instrument[s]" they developed called Raads to record a piece created for the song.<ref name="Star">{{cite news |title=Trio gives U2 Raad-ical strings |newspaper=[[Toronto Star]] |date=20 March 1987 |page=D14}}</ref> Dick Armin said, "[U2] were interested in using strings, but not in the conventional style of sweetening. They didn't want a 19th-century group playing behind them."<ref name="Star" /> Bono found the song so emotional, he was unable to listen to it after it had been recorded.<ref>Kootnikoff (2010), pp. 60–61</ref>
In the song, Bono included the lyric: "Jara sang, his song a weapon in the hands of love / You know his blood still cries from the ground". This refers to the Chilean political activist and folk singer [[Víctor Jara]], who became a symbol of the resistance against the [[Augusto Pinochet]] military dictatorship after he was tortured and killed during the [[1973 Chilean coup d'état]].<ref name="album notes2007">{{cite AV media notes |title=The Joshua Tree 20th anniversary edition |others=U2 |year=2007 |publisher=[[Island Records]] |type=Boxset |location=Canada |id=B0010304-00}}</ref> Bono learned of Jara after meeting René Castro, a Chilean mural artist, while on [[Amnesty International]]'s [[A Conspiracy of Hope]] tour. Castro had been tortured and held in a concentration camp for two years by the military because his artwork criticised the Pinochet-led [[Military government of Chile (1973–1990)|regime]] that had seized power in 1973 during the coup.<ref>de la Parra (2003), p. 76</ref> While purchasing a [[screen printing|silkscreen]] of [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] that Castro had created, Bono noticed a print of Jara.<ref name="album notes2007" /><ref>{{cite journal |last=Mueller |first=Andrew |authorlink=Andrew Mueller |date=April 2009 |title=The Joshua Tree |issue=U2 |page=59 |work=''[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]] Ultimate Music Guide''}}</ref> He became more familiar with him after reading ''Una Canción Truncada'' (An Unfinished Song), written by Jara's widow Joan Turner.<ref name="album notes2007" />
"One Tree Hill" and ''The Joshua Tree'' are dedicated to Carroll's memory.<ref>{{cite journal |orig-year=Originally published 14 March 1987 |editor-last=Jones |editor-first=Allan |date=April 2009 |journal=The Ultimate Music Guide |issue=U2 |pages=60–69 |publisher=''Uncut'' ||first=Colin |last=Irwin |title=Once, we were asked to set up an audience with the Pope ...}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=The Joshua Tree |others=U2 |year=1987 |publisher=Island Records |type=Vinyl |id=U2 6 |location=United Kingdom}}</ref> The track was recorded by [[Flood (producer)|Flood]] and [[Pat McCarthy (record producer)|Pat McCarthy]], mixed by Dave Meegan, and produced by Lanois and Eno.<ref name="release1" />
==Composition and theme== {{listen |pos=right |filename=U2 One Tree Hill sample.ogg |title="One Tree Hill" |description=Thirty-second sample of "One Tree Hill" containing lyrical references to Victor Jara and the funeral of Greg Carroll|format=[[Ogg]]}}
"One Tree Hill" runs for 5 minutes, 23 seconds. It is played in [[Time signature|common time]] at a [[tempo]] of 120 beats per minute.<ref name="Sheets">Chipkin (1999), pp. 69–77</ref> The song begins with a highlife-influenced riff by the Edge on guitar, which repeats in the background throughout the song.<ref name="album notes2007" /><ref name="Sheets" /> Percussion from drummer [[Larry Mullen, Jr.]] enters after two seconds. At 0:07, a second guitar enters. At 0:15, Clayton's bass and Mullen's drums enter, and at 0:31, the verse chord progression of C–F–B{{music|flat}}–F–C is introduced.<ref name="album notes2007" /><ref name="Sheets" /> The first verse begins at 0:47. At 1:32, the song moves to the chorus, switching to a C–B{{music|flat}}–F–C chord progression. The second verse then begins at 1:49, and after the second chorus, a brief musical interlude begins at 2:36, in which the Edge's guitar is replaced by the Raad strings.<ref name="album notes2007" /> The third verse begins at 3:07, and the Edge's guitar resumes at 3:38 in the chorus. A guitar solo begins at 4:16 and is played until the instrumentation comes to a close at 4:36. After two seconds of silence, the Raad strings fade in and Bono proceeds to sing the coda. The final lyric and strings fade out over the final six seconds.<ref name="album notes2007"/>
Clayton called it part of a trilogy of songs on the album, along with "[[Bullet the Blue Sky]]" and "[[Mothers of the Disappeared]]", that decry the involvement of the United States in the Chilean coup.<ref name="album notes2007" /> McGuinness stated that the imagery in the song described the sense of tragedy felt by the band over Carroll's death.<ref name="Phantom" /> Colm O'Hare of ''[[Hot Press]]'' believed the Edge's guitar riff personified the lyric "run like a river runs to the sea".<ref name="Hare" /> Thom Duffy of the ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'' felt the song reflected the seduction of a lover.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1987-03-22/entertainment/0120000208_1_u2-joshua-hewson |title=U2 |newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |first=Thom |last=Duffy |date=22 March 1987 |accessdate=26 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61zk0cjrU?url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1987-03-22/entertainment/0120000208_1_u2-joshua-hewson |archivedate=26 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Richard Harrington of the ''[[Washington Post]]'' acknowledged the tribute to Carroll, adding that it demonstrated U2's belief that music could spur change.<ref>{{cite news |title=U2 Can Be Famous; Breaking Into the Big Time With 'Joshua Tree' |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |first=Richard |last=Harrington |date=22 March 1987 |page=G1}}</ref>
Like many other U2 songs, "One Tree Hill" can be interpreted in a religious manner. ''Hot Press'' editor [[Niall Stokes]] called it "a spiritual tour de force", saying "it is a hymn of praise and celebration which described the traditional Māori burial of their friend on One Tree Hill and links it poetically with themes of renewal and redemption."<ref name="Stokes" /> Beth Maynard, a Church [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]] from Fairhaven, Massachusetts, felt the song "vows faith in the face of loss, combining elegiac lines about a friend ... and the martyred Chilean activist and folk singer Victor Jara, with a subtle evocation of end-time redemption and a wrenching wail to God to send the pentecostal Latter Rain."<ref>Whiteley (2003), p. 170</ref> Matt Soper, Senior Minister of the West Houston Church of Christ, believed the lyrics were an attempt by Bono to understand God's place in the world.<ref>Soper (2010), p. 72</ref> Steve Stockman, a chaplain at [[Queen's University Belfast]], felt that the song alluded to "transcendent places beyond the space and time of earth".<ref>Stockman (2005), p. 68</ref> Music journalist Bill Graham noted "the lyrics, with their reference to traditional Māori burial ceremonies on One Tree Hill, indicated that the band's faith didn't exclude an empathy with others' beliefs and rituals. Their Christianity wouldn't plaster over the universal archetypes of mourning."<ref name="Graham" /> {{clear}}
==Release and reception== "One Tree Hill" was released on ''The Joshua Tree'' on 9 March 1987 as the ninth song on the album.<ref name="billboard"/> Some CD pressings incorrectly split the [[track (CD)|track]]s, with the song's coda included as part of the track for the following song, "[[Exit (U2 song)|Exit]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://diffuser.fm/u2-exit/|title=U2 Plunge Into Darkness on 'Exit': The Story Behind Every 'Joshua Tree' Song|first=Michael|last=Christopher|date=9 March 2017|accessdate=20 June 2017|work=[[Diffuser.fm]]}}</ref> In New Zealand and Australia, "One Tree Hill" was released as a [[Gramophone record#Common formats|7-inch]] single in New Zealand and Australia in March 1988.<ref name="release1" /><ref name="release2" /> The cover art (photographed by [[Anton Corbijn]]), sleeve (designed by [[Steve Averill]]), and B-sides ("Bullet the Blue Sky" and "[[Running to Stand Still]]") were identical to those used for U2's 1987 single "[[In God's Country]]", released only in North America.<ref name="release1" /><ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=In God's Country |publisher=Island Records |id=IS-1167 |location=Canada |date=1987 |others=U2 |type=12" vinyl}}</ref> A [[cassette single]], available only in New Zealand, was also released.<ref name="release3" /> The song reached number one on the [[New Zealand Singles Chart]].<ref name="Chart" /> "One Tree Hill" was included as a bonus track on the Japanese version of U2's 1998 compilation album, ''[[The Best of 1980–1990]]''.<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=The Best of 1980–1990 |others=U2 |year=1998 |publisher=Island Records |type=CD |id=PHCR–1885 |location=Japan}}</ref> The [[The Best of 1980–1990#Video|accompanying video compilation]] included the song's [[music video]], directed by [[Phil Joanou]], which features a live performance taken from a previously unreleased cut of U2's 1988 [[rockumentary]] ''[[Rattle and Hum]]''.<ref>{{cite video |people=[[Bono]], [[the Edge]], [[Adam Clayton]], [[Larry Mullen, Jr.]] |date=April 1999 |title=The Best of 1980–1990 |medium=Videotape |publisher=[[PolyGram]]}}</ref> Additional live performances were released on the [[Digital distribution|digital]] album ''[[Live from the Point Depot]]'' (2004) and the U2.com member-exclusive album ''[[U22 (album)|U22]]'' (2012).<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Live from the Point Depot |others=U2 |year=2004 |publisher=Island Records |type=Digital download}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ultimateclassicrock.com/u2-release-crowd-selected-u22-live-album-via-fan-club/|title=U2 Release Crowd-Selected 'U22' Live Album Via Fan Club|first=Chad|last=Childers|date=21 June 2012|accessdate=7 June 2017|work=[[Ultimate Classic Rock]]}}</ref> Select editions of the 30th anniversary release of ''The Joshua Tree'' in 2017 featured a [[remix]] of "One Tree Hill" by St Francis Hotel and a new mix of the song's reprise by Brian Eno.<ref name="billboard">{{Cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/7717912/u2-joshua-tree-30th-anniversary-edition-bonus-live-tracks-photos|title=U2 Prepping 'The Joshua Tree' 30th Anniversary Edition With Bonus Tracks, Live Cuts & Unseen Photos|first=Gil|last=Kaufman|date=9 March 2017|accessdate=7 June 2017|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref>
"One Tree Hill" was received favourably by critics. ''Hot Press'' editor Niall Stokes described it as one of U2's best tracks, calling it a "fitting tribute" to Carroll.<ref name="Stokes" /> The ''[[Toronto Star]]'' felt it was one of the best songs on the album.<ref name="Star" /> Steve Morse of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' compared Bono's vocals at the song's conclusion to the passion of American [[soul music|soul singer]] [[Otis Redding]], also noting that the coda was reminiscent of the hymn "[[Amazing Grace]]".<ref name="Morse">{{cite news |title=U2's ''The Joshua Tree'': A Spiritual Progress Report |newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] |last=Morse |first=Steve |date=1 March 1987 |page=B32 |quote=[Bono's] emotional outpouring at the end ... has a passion on a par with peak-period Otis Redding. The song eventually winds down to a gospel improvisation that recalls the tenderness of 'Amazing Grace'.}}</ref> Steve Pond of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' called it "a soft, haunting benediction".<ref name="Pond">{{cite journal|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/the-joshua-tree-19870409 |title=Review: The Joshua Tree |first=Steve |last=Pond |work=Rolling Stone |date=9 April 1987 |issue=497 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5w6vKcY74?url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/the-joshua-tree-19870409 |archivedate=30 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Bill Graham of ''Hot Press'' said the song was "hopeful, not grim", describing the lyric "We run like a river to the sea" as "[musician Mike Scott's] metaphor recast in terms of eternal life and the Maori's own belief."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hotpress.com/archive/551787.html |title=The Joshua Tree |first=Bill |last=Graham |work=Hot Press |date=February 1987 |accessdate=26 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61znGSVz0?url=http://hotpress.com/archive/551787.html |archivedate=26 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> He described the Edge's playing as "a loose-limbed guitar melody with both an African and a Hawaiian tinge", concluding by saying "despite its moving vocal coda, 'One Tree Hill' isn't sombre. It celebrates the life of the spirit not its extinction."<ref name="Graham">Graham (2004), pp. 34–35</ref>
Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', John Rockwell felt that it was an example of U2 stretching their range, saying "the inclusion of musical idioms [is] never so overtly explored before on a U2 record, especially the gospel chorus of 'One Tree Hill'".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/arts/u2-makes-a-bid-for-great-band-status.html?pagewanted=3&src=pm |title=U2 makes a bid for 'great band' status |first=John |last=Rockwell |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=29 March 1987 |accessdate=25 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61yJl1pKX?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/arts/u2-makes-a-bid-for-great-band-status.html?pagewanted=3&src=pm |archivedate=25 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Colin Hogg of ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]'' called it "a remarkable musical centrepiece", believing it to be the best song on the album.<ref name="Hogg">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=10411209 |title=Album review: The Joshua Tree |newspaper=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |date=20 March 1987 |first=Colin |last=Hogg |accessdate=1 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wAAtIr2z?url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=10411209 |archivedate=1 February 2011 |quote=... not only is it a song that means a lot in this part of the world, but it is the album's finest, saddest melody and its most heartfelt performance, building in urgency until Bono's voice just explodes to the song's climax. |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Colm O'Hare of ''Hot Press'' said it was "arguably the most poignant, emotionally-charged song U2 have ever recorded."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hotpress.com/archive/4269254.html?new_layout=1&page_no=14&show_comments=1 |title=The Secret History of 'The Joshua Tree' 14/18 |first=Colm |last=O'Hare |work=Hot Press |date=21 November 2007 |accessdate=26 September 2011 |archivedate=26 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61zi6VlJb?url=http://www.hotpress.com/archive/4269254.html?new_layout=1&page_no=14&show_comments=1 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> He added that it was the "least instrumentally adorned song on the album, resplendent in a feeling of space and openness."<ref name="Hare" /> McGuinness called it one of his favourite U2 songs.<ref name="Propaganda" />
The American television drama ''[[One Tree Hill (TV series)|One Tree Hill]]'' was named for the song after series creator [[Mark Schwahn]] was listening to ''The Joshua Tree'' when writing the idea for the show.<ref name="Documentary">{{cite video|title=''"Building a Winning Team: The Making of ''One Tree Hill''"''. [[One Tree Hill (TV series)|One Tree Hill]]: The Complete First Season|medium=Documentary|publisher=[[Warner Bros.]]|date=2005}}</ref> "One Tree Hill" was also the name of the [[series finale]], which featured the song in the episode's final scene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/one-tree-hill/one-tree-hill-series-finale-re-44858.aspx|title={{-'}}One Tree Hill' Series Finale Recap: Goodbye to a Magical Place|date=4 April 2012|work=[[BuddyTV]]|first=John|last=Kubicek|accessdate=7 June 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170526091841/http://www.buddytv.com/articles/one-tree-hill/one-tree-hill-series-finale-re-44858.aspx|archive-date=26 May 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Live performances== {{Quote box|quote="We've never performed 'One Tree Hill', and I can't. In fact I haven't even heard the song, though I've listened to it a hundred times. I've cut myself off from it completely."|source=—Bono in 1987<ref name="RS">{{cite journal |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |title=Interview with Bono |first=David |last=Breskin |date=8 October 1987}}</ref> |width=25% |align=left |style=padding:8px;}}
"One Tree Hill" made its live debut on 10 September 1987 in Uniondale, New York, the opening night of the third leg of the [[Joshua Tree Tour]], where it opened the encore.<ref name="Parra111">de la Parra (2003), p. 111</ref> The song had been left out of the set up to this point because Bono feared he would be unable to overcome his emotions in the live setting.<ref name="Parra111" /> Despite his fears, the song received an enthusiastic reaction from the audience.<ref name="Parra111" /> It was performed a further six times and then dropped from the show for a period of two months. It was revived in the main set on 17 November 1987 in Los Angeles, California, and played a further nine times on the tour.<ref>de la Parra (2003), pp. 117–121</ref> "One Tree Hill" was played occasionally on the [[Lovetown Tour]], appearing at 19 of 47 concerts.<ref>de la Parra (2003), pp. 123–138</ref> The penultimate performance, on 31 December 1989, was broadcast live on radio to 21 countries throughout Europe as a New Year's Eve present from the band.<ref>de la Parra (2003), p. 135</ref>
[[File:One Tree Hill 2006 by MJM NZ crop.jpg|thumb|right|U2 performing "One Tree Hill" in Auckland in 2006]]
"One Tree Hill" was absent during the majority of the [[Zoo TV Tour]], only appearing as an extended snippet at the end of "[[One (U2 song)|One]]" at both concerts in New Zealand in 1993.<ref>de la Parra (2003), p. 172</ref> It did not appear again until 24 November 2006 in Auckland, New Zealand, on the final leg of the [[Vertigo Tour]]. It was considered to close the concert, but tour designer [[Willie Williams (set designer)|Willie Williams]] voiced concern as it had not been performed in full since 1990. The song was performed before "[[Sometimes You Can't Make It on Your Own]]" in the main set instead.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.u2.com/tour/article/title/show-day-auckland/willies_diary_360/76/313 |title=Willie's Diary: Show Day, Auckland |date=24 November 2006 |first=Willie |last=Williams |authorlink=Willie Williams (set designer) |work=U2.com |publisher=[[Live Nation]] |accessdate=25 September 2011}} {{Subscription}}</ref> U2 performed it an additional three times on the tour.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Cohen |first=Jonathon |title=From Joshua Trees to Palm Trees |date=6 January 2007 |journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |volume=119 |issue=1 |issn=0006-2510 |publisher=Nielsen Business Media |pages=16–17}}</ref> "One Tree Hill" was absent for the majority of the [[U2 360° Tour]] but was revived in November 2010 for two concerts in New Zealand, where it was dedicated to the miners who died in the [[Pike River Mine disaster]]; their names were displayed on the video screen during the song.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.u2.com/tour/date/id/4511 |title=November 25, 2010: Auckland, NZ (Mt. Smart Stadium) show report |date=25 November 2010 |accessdate=25 September 2011 |work=U2.com |publisher=Live Nation |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61xw92ZdZ?url=http://www.u2.com/tour/date/id/4511 |archivedate=25 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=U2 tribute to lost coal miners touches New Zealand |date=26 November 2010 |url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/u2-tribute-to-lost-coal-miners-touches-new-zealand-20101126-18a1d.html |first=Nicholas |last=Russell |accessdate=26 November 2010 |work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61xwBOOyK?url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/u2-tribute-to-lost-coal-miners-touches-new-zealand-20101126-18a1d.html |archivedate=25 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Dedicating the song, Bono said, "we wrote it for Greg Carroll, whose family are with us tonight. But tonight it belongs to the miners of the West Coast Pike River."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.u2.com/tour/date/id/4527 |title=November 26, 2010: Auckland, NZ (Mt. Smart Stadium) show report |date=26 November 2010 |accessdate=25 September 2011 |work=U2.com |publisher=Live Nation |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61xwEy8bk?url=http://www.u2.com/tour/date/id/4527 |archivedate=25 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> U2 played "One Tree Hill" on 25 March 2011, in Santiago, Chile, in a duet with [[Francisca Valenzuela]], and they dedicated it to Victor Jara.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.u2.com/tour/date/id/4558 |title=March 25, 2011: Santiago, CL (Estadio Nacional) show report |date=25 March 2011 |accessdate=25 September 2011 |work=U2.com |publisher=Live Nation |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61xwHYEne?url=http://www.u2.com/tour/date/id/4558 |archivedate=25 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It was also played in an unplanned addition to the encore at a show in Chicago on 5 July 2011 to mark the 25th anniversary of the death of Greg Carroll <ref>https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/u2/2011/soldier-field-chicago-il-23d36493.html</ref>
In 2009, when asked about the likelihood of U2 performing the song, the Edge said, "it's one we kind of keep for special occasions, like playing New Zealand."<ref name=therock/> Bono added, "it's a very special song that holds inside of it a lot of strong feelings, and I don't know if we're afraid of it or something, but we should be playing it more."<ref name="therock">{{cite video |title=Exclusive Interview with Bono and the Edge |people=Bono; the Edge |publisher=[[The Rock (New Zealand)|The Rock]]. [[MediaWorks New Zealand]] |location=New Zealand |medium=Radio broadcast |time=4:16 |date=2 September 2010 |url=http://www.therock.net.nz/NZ-Exclusive-The-Rock-Interview-Bono-And-The-Edge-From-U2/tabid/381/articleID/11494/Default.aspx}}</ref> McGuinness said that U2 found it difficult to play live.<ref name="Propaganda">{{cite journal |title=Absolute McGuinness |date=October 1987 |journal=Propaganda |issue=7}}</ref>
"One Tree Hill" returned to live performances during [[the Joshua Tree Tour 2017]], which featured 51 concerts from May through October 2017, each of which featured a full performance of the entire ''Joshua Tree'' album in running order.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/7824627/u2-adds-joshua-tree-tour-dates|title=U2 Adds Joshua Tree Tour Dates|first=Colin|last=Stutz|date=6 June 2017|accessdate=8 June 2017|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/u2-celebrate-30th-anniversary-joshua-9589457|title=U2 will celebrate 30th anniversary of The Joshua Tree by playing full album every night on world tour this summer|first=Lara|last=Martin|date=9 January 2017|accessdate=8 June 2017|work=[[Daily Mirror]]}}</ref> Each song from the album was accompanied by a film shown on the set's [[LED display]] that served as a backdrop to the band's performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/music/u2-launch-of-joshua-tree-tour-in-vancouver-had-trump-in-its-shadows/article34981864/|title=U2 launch of ‘Joshua Tree’ tour in Vancouver had Trump in its shadows|first=Marsha|last=Lederman|date=13 May 2017|accessdate=12 September 2018}}</ref> The film played during "One Tree Hill" featured an image large red moon along that faded into footage of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atu2.com/news/column-off-the-record--vol-17-761.html|title=Column: Off the Record... Vol. 17-761|first=Sherry|last=Lawrence|work=@U2|date=13 May 2017|accessdate=12 September 2018}}</ref> It was directed by Anton Corbijn and filmed in [[Lancaster, California]] over a 14-hour film shoot.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atu2.com/news/meet-the-navajo-woman-in-u2s-one-tree-hill-joshua-tree-tour-video.html|title=Meet the Navajo woman in U2's 'One Tree Hill' Joshua Tree Tour video|first=Karen|last=Lindell|work=@U2|date=31 May 2017|accessdate=12 September 2018}}</ref> Bono dedicated performances of the song to singer [[Chris Cornell]] (who died in May 2017),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/7801138/u2-bono-the-edge-chris-cornell-soundgarden-rose-bowl-joshua-tree-tour|title=U2 Pays Tribute to Chris Cornell During 'Joshua Tree' Concert at L.A.'s Rose Bowl|date=21 May 2017|accessdate=8 June 2017|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref> to singer [[Chester Bennington]] (who died in July 2017),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2017/music/news/concert-review-linkin-park-and-friends-hollywood-bowl-three-hour-chester-bennington-tribute-1202601680/ |title= Linkin Park and Friends Light Up the Hollywood Bowl With Three-Hour Chester Bennington Tribute |last=Baltin |first=Steve |date=28 October 2017 |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]] |access-date=29 December 2017}}</ref> to the victims of the [[Manchester Arena bombing]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/daily/music/2017-05-25/exit-u2/|title=Exit U2: In revisiting The Joshua Tree, the Dubliners return home|work=[[The Austin Chronicle]]|date=25 May 2017|accessdate=8 June 2017|first=Raoul|last=Hernandez}}</ref> and to the victims of the [[Orlando nightclub shooting]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/opinion/central-florida-100/os-ed-bono-honors-49-who-died-in-pulse-nightclub-central-florida-100-htmlstory.html|title=U2-Pulse connection: I Still Haven't Found What I'm Looking For|first=Mark|last=Fried|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|date=17 June 2017|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
==Track listing== {{Track listing |headline=7" vinyl,<ref name="release1">{{cite AV media notes |title=One Tree Hill |publisher=Island Records |id=878 302-7 |location=New Zealand |date=1988 |others=U2 |type=7" vinyl}}</ref><ref name="release2">{{cite AV media notes |title=One Tree Hill |publisher=Island Records |id=K-338 |location=Australia |date=1988 |others=U2 |type=7" vinyl}}</ref> cassette<ref name="release3">{{cite AV media notes |title=One Tree Hill |publisher=Island Records |id=878 302-4 |location=New Zealand |date=1988 |others=U2 |type=7" vinyl}}</ref> |total_length=14:15 |all_music=U2 |all_lyrics=Bono |title1=One Tree Hill |length1=5:23 |title2=[[Bullet the Blue Sky]] |length2=4:32 |title3=[[Running to Stand Still]] |length3=4:20 }}
==Credits and personnel== {{col-begin}} {{col-3}} '''U2'''<ref name="release1" /> *[[Bono]] – [[lead vocalist|vocals]] *[[The Edge]] – [[guitar]], [[backing vocalist|backing vocals]] *[[Adam Clayton]] – [[bass guitar]] *[[Larry Mullen, Jr.]] – [[Drum kit|drums]], [[percussion instrument|percussion]] {{col-break}} '''Additional performers'''<ref name="Star" /><ref name="album notes2007" /> *Dick Armin – Raad cello *Paul Armin – Raad viola *Adele Armin – Raad violin {{col-break}} '''Technical'''<ref name="release1" /> *[[Record producer|Production]] – [[Brian Eno]], [[Daniel Lanois]] *[[Sound recording and reproduction|Recording]] – [[Flood (producer)|Flood]] *Recording assistance – Pat McCarthy *[[Audio mixing (recorded music)|Mixing]] – Dave Meegan {{col-end}}
==Charts== {|class="wikitable" !Chart (1988) !Peak<br>position |- |[[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand|New Zealand Singles Chart]]<ref name="Chart">{{cite web |url=http://www.ultratop.be/en/showitem.asp?interpret=U2&titel=One+Tree+Hill&cat=s |title=U2 – One Tree Hill |work=Ultratop |accessdate=24 November 2009}}</ref> |align="center"|1 |}
==See also== *[[List of cover versions of U2 songs#One Tree Hill|List of cover versions of U2 songs – One Tree Hill]]
==References== '''Footnotes''' {{reflist|30em}}
'''Bibliography''' {{refbegin}} *{{cite book |last=Chipkin |first=Kenn |title=U2 – The Joshua Tree: Authentic Record Transcriptions |publisher=Alfred Music Publishing |location=London |year=1999 |isbn=978-0-7119-1315-8}} *{{cite book |last=de la Parra |first=Pimm Jal |title=U2 Live: A Concert Documentary |publisher=Omnibus Press |location=New York |year=2003 |edition=second |isbn=978-0-7119-9198-9}} *{{cite book |last1=Graham |first1=Bill |author2=van Oosten de Boer, Caroline |title=U2: The Complete Guide to Their Music |year=2004 |publisher=Omnibus Press |location=London |isbn=0-7119-9886-8}} *{{cite book |last=Kootnikoff |first=David |title=U2: A Musical Biography |year=2010 |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=Santa Barbara |isbn=0-313-36523-7}} *{{cite book |last=Soper |first=Matt |title=Raising Up a Testimony: Essays on Christianity in America |year=2010 |publisher=Xulon Press |location=Longwood, Florida |isbn=978-1-60957-818-3}} *{{cite book |title=Walk On: The Spiritual Journey of U2 |first=Steve |last=Stockman |publisher=Relevant Books| location=Orlando |year=2005 |edition=Revised |isbn=0-9760357-5-8}} *{{cite book |last=Stokes |first=Niall |authorlink=Niall Stokes |title=U2: Into The Heart: The Stories Behind Every Song |publisher=Thunder's Mouth Press |location=New York |year=2005 |edition=Third |isbn=1-56025-765-2}} *{{cite book |author=U2 |editor1-first=Neil |editor1-last=McCormick |title=U2 by U2 |publisher=HarperCollins |location=London |year=2006 |isbn=0-00-719668-7}} *{{cite book |last1=Whiteley |first1=Raewynne J. |last2=Maynard |first2=Beth |title=Get Up Off Your Knees: Preaching the U2 Catalog |publisher=Cowley Publications |location=Cambridge, Massachusetts |year=2003 |series=The New Church's Teachings. |isbn=978-1-56101-223-7}} {{refend}}

revision.comment: /* Young Artist Programme */Fixing [[WP:CHECKWIKI]] #16: unicode contol character (and other minor general edits caused by AWB), replaced: →
revision.text:
'''Les Azuriales Opera''' is an Anglo-French organisation that focuses on finding outstanding young artists and making a significant difference to their early operatic careers. Its activities take place in Cap Ferrat, Villefranche-sur-Mer and London.
== Young Artist Programme == Les Azuriales Young Artist Programme, lasting approximately two weeks, takes place each year in August at the [[Villa Ephrussi de Rothschild]] on [[Cap Ferrat]], and the {{ill|Citadelle Saint-Elme|fr}} in [[Villefranche-sur-Mer]], both on the [[Côte d'Azur]] near Nice in France. The programme consists of a singing competition (with prizes of €10,000), public and private masterclasses and an opera performance put together from scratch in a week.
Each year more than 100 singers from around the world are auditioned and 8 to 10 are chosen to become Les Azuriales Young Artists. Les Azuriales has strong links with South Korea, South Africa, Armenia and Russia.
The distinguished givers of its public [[master class]]es and private workshops have included: Lucy Arner, [[Sally Burgess]], [[Peter Coleman-Wright]], [[Michèle Crider]], Sarah-Jane Davies, Peter Kazaras, [[Lyubov Kazarnovskaya|Ljuba Kazarnovskaya]], Elaine Kidd, [[Martin Lloyd-Evans]], Emanuele Moris, [[Dennis O'Neill (tenor)|Dennis O'Neill]], Pedro Ribeiro, Brindley Sherratt and Alessandro Talevi.
A number of its young artists have been winners or finalists of major competitions, including the Montserrat Caballé Prize, the [[Kathleen Ferrier Award]], the Stella Maris awards and [[BBC Cardiff Singer of the World competition|Cardiff Singer of the World]].
Seven of its alumni have joined London's [[The Royal Opera|Royal Opera]]’s Jette Parker Young Artists programme. Others have been to the [[National Opera Studio]] (UK), [[Vienna State Opera]] and other prestigious programmes.
Les Azuriales Opera is unusual as a young artist programme in that it provides on going moral and financial support to its young artists.
== Background == Les Azuriales Opera is administered almost entirely by volunteers (as opposed to the musical organisation, which is entirely professional). It is privately funded by private and corporate donors.
The structure consists of * Les Azuriales Opera Trust – a UK registered charity<ref>[http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithoutPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1077210&SubsidiaryNumber=0 Charity Commission entry]</ref> * L'Association des Amis du Festival "Les Azuriales" – the official organisation that runs Les Azuriales activities in France: it is an officially registered "Association" (Siret: 440 834 349 00019) * A Comité d'Honneur whose members provide support and advice. its members are: Richard Salter, [[Vernon Ellis|Sir Vernon Ellis]], [[Antoinette Sibley|Dame Antoinette Sibley]] and [[Christopher Hampson]].
The musical organisation is under the guidance of Bryan Evans, the music director of Diva Opera, who is also Les Azuriales' music director. Sarah-Jane Davies, head of casting at [[Scottish Opera]], plays a key role as artistic consultant and Alessandro Talevi is Les Azuriales' resident guest director.
== History == In 1996 Sarah Holford, an English commercial barrister, was introduced to Bryan Evans who had recently founded a chamber opera company in England, Diva Opera. Evans had been presenting chamber opera in country houses and similar venues for many years. With support from Diva Opera in 1997 Sarah Holford founded Les Azuriales Opera Festival principally centred on the [[Villa Ephrussi de Rothschild]] on Cap Ferrat: she had been visiting the area almost every year since she was a child. Diva Opera became the long term opera partner of the festival and itself continues to perform opera in many parts of Europe. Another major contributor was Dominique Lelandais, a resident of St Jean, whose drive and local knowledge were key factors in bringing the festival to life.
In 2003 Les Azuriales started its Young Artist Programme as part of its festival.
In 2015 Les Azuriales ceased to be present an opera festival and changed to its present format with its summer season concentrating solely on its Young Artist Programme,
==See also== *[[List of opera festivals]]
==References== <references />
==External links== *{{official|https://www.azurialopera.com}} *[http://www.divaopera.com/ Diva Opera's official website]

revision.text:
[[File:Chincoteague pony swim 2007.jpg|thumb|Chincoteague ponies arriving on Chincoteague after swimming the channel]] [[File:Chincoteague Pony Swim 1.jpg|thumb|Salt water cowboys driving ponies to Chincoteague Carnival Grounds]] [[File:Pony Auction during 2008 Pony Penning 001.jpg|thumb|Pony Auction 2008]]
'''Pony Penning''' is an annual event held in [[Chincoteague, Virginia|Chincoteague]], [[Virginia]] on the last consecutive Wednesday and Thursday in July. The [[Chincoteague Fire Department|Chincoteague Volunteer Fire Department]] conducts the event and it consists of a Wild Pony Swim on Wednesday and a Pony Auction on Thursday. For the Wild Pony Swim, Salt Water Cowboys round up feral [[Chincoteague Pony|Chincoteague Ponies]] from [[Assateague Island]] and drive them across the [[Assateague Channel]] to Veteran’s Memorial Park on [[Chincoteague, Virginia|Chincoteague Island]].<ref name=Wed-Thur>''Chincoteague Beachcomber''. "Pony Penning Wed., Thurs.", July 25, 2008, p. 2.</ref> The ponies swim across the channel during [[Slack water|slack tide]], when the water has minimal tidal movement.<ref name=Wed-Thur/> Once on Chincoteague Island, the salt water cowboys herd the ponies to pens on the Chincoteague Carnival Grounds where some of the foals are auctioned off on Thursday.<ref name=How_did>Gooldrup, Harley. ''Chincoteague Beachcomber''. "How did the ponies get to the island?", July 25, 2008, p. 5.</ref>
This traditional event in its current form has taken place since 1925 to raise money for the Chincoteague Volunteer Fire Department, but its roots date back to the 17th century.<ref name=Wed-Thur/><ref name=How_did/> The event was popularized by the book ''[[Misty of Chincoteague]]'' by [[Marguerite Henry]], published in 1947. It now usually draws from 40,000 to 50,000 spectators.<ref name=Wed-Thur/>
==See also== *[[History of Chincoteague, Virginia]]
==Notes== <references/>
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.chincoteaguechamber.com/pony-swim }}
{{commons category}}
